Food was bland and overpriced. Ordered their Katsudon, gyoza, and takoyaki to go since there was such a long lineup. It came up to $50+ for these three dishes. The katsu and gyoza had almost no flavour and the takoyaki had only a small piece of octopus in each ball. A letdown since I really wanted to like this place due to its reviews.

The restaurant serves delicious food, evident from the Japanese customers who frequent the place. Although they accidentally overlooked one of our dishes, they kindly offered to waive the cost of the potato salad to ensure our satisfaction.

The ramen was sooo delicious. You definitely get a good bang for your buck for the serving size. It’s definitely worth the stop, especially since this place is one of the oldest Ramen restaurants in Los Angeles. With that being said, it’s a little outdated inside but I feel like that added to the vibe. They also have a cute cat robot they use when it begins to get packed, that was cool to see and added excitement!!
This is a great place to eat traditional Japanese food. The ramen was great. I usually don’t finish it but it was so yummy so I savored every bite and finished everything.

name: Chinchikurin Little Tokyo
address: 350 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
This place should have a rating of 5.0, I've had dinner at Chinchikurin about three times now. Despite how busy they are, the staff are attentive, kind, and welcoming.  The team instantly recognized us after our third visit. Mind you, we are not from this country. The food is great, warm, delicious and so so so good after a long day. The atmosphere is perfect. We usually pick the patio, but the indoor seating is just as great. It's my favorite spot, and it will always be a place I visit whenever I fly into LA.  Thank you to the staff working the dinner shift July 5-6. You have been amazing!!! I hope they continue to thrive and succeed. I wish nothing but the best for Chinchikurin. I'm not sure if I'll see the same staff next year, but I wish them the best and hope only good things come their way.
Hands down, it's the best place to eat at, especially if you're in town for AX.
-Joori, party for 2

I ordered the TanTan Ramen, the noodles were good but the broth was too strong (salty) for my liking. There wasnt much toppings on it either even though it was $17. Good amount of green onion though. The deep fried chicken was such a small portion for $14 and honestly not that good.

When you visit Little Tokyo in LA, the first restaurant you will see is the Chinchikurin. The Hiroshima based restaurant chain brings Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki to Los Angeles. Unlike its Osaka counterpart, this dish is a symphony of layers—crepe-like batter, tender cabbage, fish flour, crispy tempura bits, and yakisoba noodles. Each ingredient is meticulously stacked, creating a harmonious blend of taste and texture.

Hiroshima-style okonomiyaki has a fascinating history. In the aftermath of World War II, Hiroshima faced scarcity, yet resilience prevailed. The locals ingeniously transformed U.S. military-supplied flour into a pancake—a humble sustenance that evolved into okonomiyaki. This dish, reminiscent of “issen-yoshoku,” became a symbol of survival and community.

Our visit on a Saturday brought us to savor two variations: the Spicy Goam and the tender octopus noodle. The soft noodle version stole our hearts. The balance of flavors—savory, slightly sweet, and umami—left us craving more.

Chinchikurin allows LA residents to savor authentic Japanese cuisine without crossing the Pacific. Efficient service and nearby parking at Japanese Village Plaza make it a delightful spot for food enthusiasts.

Known for hiroshima style okonomiyaki. Arrive around 15 min before it opened and was able to get seated quickly. Besides ordering the special seafood okonomiyaki, we also ordered karaage and several types of takoyaki (there was a variety to try). Everything was well presented and tasted great. This place is always popular with long lines whenever I visited lil tokyo and I can see why. If you really want to try this go early or expect to wait (will be worth it)

First time here with my nephew. I almost ordered ramen but changed my mind last minute because the whole point was to experience okonomiyaki. You come here for that. We have lots of great japanese food in San Diego but none makes Okonomiyaki. I ordered the Loaded Kaisen with the choice of Crispy Noodles. It had Shrimp and Squid on top. It was delicious. We also ordered wasabi takoyaki. I was bit surprised by the Public Parking because the price was 15$ 😬 but overall the trip to little Tokyo was all worth it.

name: Tensho
address: 418 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Tensho occupies the former Kagaya location. While it offers the required A5 Wagyu cuts, their prime cuts are marbled and have a very tender consistency; plus an expanded seafood option for the hot pot. Unless you want to take a chance, reservations are highly recommended.
Amazing experience at Tensho. Wonderfully attentive staff and delicious dishes. Especially recommend the Wagyu Sushi that just melts in your mouth. Great for a special night out in Little Tokyo!

One of the best restaurants my friends and I went to during our LA trip. Agumi, our server, was bright and attentive despite us coming in near closing time. We are so thankful for the wonderful experience and DELICIOUS food. The apps that were part of the hot-pot course meal were filled with so much flavor. Next time I come to LA, I’m definitely going to try their nigiris because the wagyu nigiri we ordered was mind-blowing!!

Female owned and operated, service & food are excellent. The appetizer and dessert were the main home runs for me. I got a sweet tooth and a thing for small delicious dishes like the monk fish and king crab that are one bite dishes.

As for the main entree it's as fresh as it gets, price is for a set meal so it's worth it. You'll definitely feel stuffed by the end even if it looks like not much. The scallops and shrimp are my favorite 🤤. Also, the creamy scallop on cucumber owner special was a great start to service. ☺️

My only feedback for the soft opening would be to reword the requirements for sharing a set meal.
The beef was top quality and the service was great as well. Super cozy nice spot. Overall great restaurant. There’s a reason they’ve been open for decades

name: Rice & Nori
address: 123 Astronaut Ellison S Onizuka St UNIT 103, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Big portion, good price, and flavourful. Ordered the spam and egg, salmon miso yuzu onigiris and they were great. A little salty but balanced by the rice. The best thing was actually the matcha horchata, refreshing and amazing.

I came with a group of my friends and they handled my allergy order perfectly. Very professional. Explained how they were going to prepare my food. Overall, handled beautifully. The food was amazing! 10/10 would recommend.
Love how cozy here! Got two spicy Lobster Shrimp. Just to let you know, they don’t do Combos or anything near that apparently. Worth the 30 minute drive.

Dude this place hits the spot.

Order a couple of sushi balls and hand rolls that are a hefty portion that can either fill you up or just the right amount to save room for desert after.

Got the beacon avocado and lobster sushi balls.

Had to get an unagi hand roll with that lychee lemonade to wash everything down.

They have a mini Merch shop with tasty on the go snacks.

There are also cute plants and bonsais.

Love the wall mural of the wave 🌊 and gold textures to make the whole place feel cozy.

The guys there are super chill and feel like the homie in the kitchen hooking you up right that it makes you feel like a boss.

Much respect to them holding it down.

This place is great for that quick lunch or that dinner hangout spot to catch up with friends.

Talking about it makes me crave it even more.

Cute and small spot that specializes in onigiri, but also has a selection of hand rolls, sashimi, and bowls. In our experience the food was pretty tasty, but it's definitely better for a light snack/quick lunch. A must try if you're in Little Tokyo.

name: TOT Little Tokyo
address: 345 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: The pork katsu curry was fantastic! Really crispy, great quality meat, and the curry was a nice thick consistency. The potato croquette was also very tasty and well fried. But the shrimp tempura was very undercooked, with the batter still goey under a first layer of very pale and chewy batter. It was super disappointing, but everything else was so good I'll consider it a fluke. Overall I'd come back to try more from their menu.

I ordered pork tender katsu and fried oysters set for lunch. Pork tender was good however oysters were tiny and not fresh at all..
Service was just fair, not usual Japanese service
This place is excellent. Friendly helpful staff, great menu, great prices. The unagi bento was excellent.

We were just walking past while exploring Little Tokyo and found this gem!

Delicious Loin Katsu, Salmon Roll and Black Pork Sausage - would recommend! Edamame was average, but still nice overall ❤️

The cuisine here is genuinely authentic Japanese, and as someone of Japanese heritage, I am thoroughly impressed with the overall quality. While I haven't explored other dining options in the area, I'm confident in recommending this establishment as a solid choice. One point to note, however, is that the service might not meet everyone's high expectations. Additionally, it's important to be aware that the restroom facilities are not accessible to the public.

name: RAKKAN Ramen DTLA
address: 359 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Well, it was dinner time, since my hotel is in Little Tokyo in Los Angeles, I've really been enjoying Asian food.  I've enjoyed Ramen a few times andhaver been disappointed.  Tonight I dined at Rakkan Tamen and really enjoyed their Ramen and Bean Sprouts Salad.  I know I say this most every time, but this was excellent.  The Bean Sprouts salad was spicy, but not overly so.  I ordered their Spicy Garnet Ramen and didn't feel it was Spicy at all.  Maybe the salad overpowered it.  It was still quite good, just not that Spicy.  Stop by, you'll enjoy yourself.  But arrive early, the seating area is small.

Had an excellent dinner here 2 nights in a row, the Spicy Garnet ramen was very tasty! Gyoza was good as well. Long wait time but food was definitely worth it!

Friendly for egg allergy with plant based noodles, though they did accidentally put an egg in my ramen that I quickly caught and they fixed. So would recommend double checking nonetheless

I like Rakkan. The food is great, the service is quick and there is usually a queue because people like eating here. The roll is great, the mushroom bun is so delicious, and the ramen is extremely good. all they need is some non-alcoholic beer and i'd be there more frequently.

Rakkan Ramen in downtown LA is a fantastic dining experience. The broth is rich and flavorful, with a perfect balance of spices. The noodles are cooked to perfection, and the toppings are fresh and abundant. The vegan options are a highlight, offering delicious alternatives without compromising on taste. The ambiance is cozy and the service is prompt and friendly. Highly recommend for any ramen enthusiast!

Is it the best vegan ramen in LA? No. Does the menu have a lot of vegan options? Heck yeah. The waitlist moves fairly quick and it’s a short walk from several parking lots, including my favorite, Aiso Street Parking.

name: Mitsuru Cafe
address: 117 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: This place is not a dine-in restaurant but more of a to-go food and snacks. I tried the rice cakes with soy glaze, perfectly chewy and good balance of sweetness.
Great for Japanese snacks. We always stop by here to get the red bean cakes. The rice cakes are also nice. I do wish they heated up the karaage fried chicken.

This place is not a dine in restaurant, it’s more of to-go food and snacks. Their dango is fresh and so good. They are specialize in skewers such as chicken karage, pork shiumai, takoyaki… they always have a line.

This place sometimes eludes me since the last few times I've been down here the shop is closed (currently only opened 4 days a week). However I finally was able to come here when it is opened and there was a huge line! This place is so popular that even after ordering imagawataki I had to wait another 30 min (other snacks on a stick have no wait). Prices have gone up, but taste and quality is the same. My only regret was buying just 4 knowing I had to wait this long.

Hate their hours, only open a few days a week but the food is really good. Especially love the chicken kaarage and shrimp ball. They also had mitarashi dango before but didnt see it when i went, i remember it to be really good.

name: OOmasa
address: 100 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
A solid Japanese spot with a great selection and customer service was great. An overall solid Little Tokyo spot.

I had their miso soup, salmon skin salad, soft shell crab appetizer, fried chicken karrage, tempura shrimp, fried tofu, salmon collar & their salmon combo. The soup was ok, the salmon skin salad was excellent along with the soft shell crab.

The chicken was delicious also and the tempura shrimp was delicious especially with the hot tempura sauce which I also used for the soft shell crab. The tofu wasn’t my style, I like it a lot more fried but the flavor was there. The salmon collar was also great.

I’d definitely come back here again and try their other menu items. A solid spot, but parking and getting there can get difficult unless you walk it.

Hideen little gem in little Tokio with amazing food and staff, shout out to Claudio for making sure our big order was perfectly executed and tasted fresh and made specially just for us. The prices are fair, and the fish is a super fresh tasting pair that is upheld with a clean and comfortable restaurant feel.
I definitely recommend you guys try them out!

One of my fav sushi spots in Little Tokyo. The sushi is consistently fresh and delicious 😋 and the service is nice.  Really like the nigiri sets, chirashi, and soft shell crab. Usually there isn't a long wait. ❤️

5 years ago this place was the bee’s knee. But having visited here recently the experience was far from expected. Prices have nearly doubled, which is expected, but the quality and taste of the food has declined sharply. I ordered the teriyaki chicken, the most basic staple in Japanese cuisine, and it was thin, tasteless, dry and seemed as if they seasoned it with water. Overall a very regretful experience. I will not be returning.

Came to this place with my out-of-town guest. It's Super Bowl Sunday and there was no wait. That's so nice because it was pretty cold outside. Parking was easy as it's Sunday and we were able to find street parking. I believe one gets two hours validation from the restaurant if you park in the Japanese Village Plaza parking.

We ordered bento box and udons and everybody was happy with the food. The udon was steaming hot and the sushi in the bento box was fresh. The service was good as well.

Definitely would love to come back to this place!

name: Torigoya
address: 123 Astronaut Ellison S Onizuka St #203, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Don't forget to reserve if you don't want to wait. Absolutely one of the best yakitori bars in LA. Authentic and delicious. Don't forget their Oyakodon!

This is my favorite place to eat Yakitori in Little Tokyo. I stopped by for dinner on a chilly night and it's so cozy inside. I visited 3 years ago during covid so business was slower than usual and tables were turning fast, however now it's probably hard to get seated.

You can smell the fragrant juices of the chicken skewers if you're anywhere on the second floor of this shopping complex. I ordered to share, beef, soft and negi chicken thighs, chicken breast, chicken wings, chicken hearts and gizzards and chicken meatballs skewers. The grill master here is Japanese and he definitely knows how to preserve the succulent texture of the juices in the meat skewers while also giving you the smokiness from the charcoal.

In addition to the yakitori they also have a la carte side items like Oyako Donburi, quite fluffy and seasoned just right and an incredible chicken broth congee that warms your soul. The name of this congee on the menu is Zousui Chicken congee with vegetables. The pricing structure is very fair given the location, our bill came out to be $65 for two people. FYI they have Kirin and Asahi on tap here!

This little izakaya is definitely worth a visit.

Torigoya is a small yakitori spot that fills up very quickly so get there when it opens or you’ll have to wait. When seated, you have a paper slip to order skewers and then they have a menu with items and prices. Their staff are hustling to serve all the guests and they were timely, despite being so busy.
Unfortunately they were out of Chicken Nanban when we ordered. All the skewers were very good, no complaints. The chicken thigh is incredibly tender, and the soft thigh is even more! The sauce is flavorful but maybe a little bit too much. They use the same sauce for any of their skewers so I prefer the salted option to let the chicken and charcoal flavor shine. Prices are average for yakitori in LA, but it tastes above average and they don’t skimp out on portion size or ingredient quality.

Long wait since we stopped by to put our name down up front at 7pm and didn’t get seated until 8:50pm. We saw so many great reviews about this place and are huge fan of izakaya, so we decided to walk to all the near by shops and got onigiri at one of the stores to hold us over. What a great call to wait since it was hand down the best skewers restaurant we’ve been to in the US. If you had a chance, get everything with sauce. There wasn’t a huge difference in flavor than dry but they’re definitely more juicy. The meat was lean and just flavorful by itself. We ordered cucumber with special sauce and ot surprisingly a delicious choice to have as a side dish. The miso sauce can also be a dip for the skewers. The sodobodon (ground chicken rice bowl) was a must. All the veggies skewers were delish as well. Cannot recommend this place enough if it wasn’t for the wait, but what good foods weren’t worth waiting for right?

Order the CHICKEN NANBAN to add to your yakitori experience. It's boneless chicken battered and deep fried, topped with an egg-potato salad with a vinegar. This dish is an amazing appetizer with texture and great balanced acid. If you
like TAKO WASABI (raw octopus and wasabi), this doesn't disappoint. The wasabi reads more refreshing than intense chili heat. I recommend shishito peppers if you're looking for a spicy gamble. I've ordered the agedashi tofu and kaarage on other occasions. They are good, but the NANBAN and TAKO WASABI are high quality and harder to find.

On this night, we couldn't go crazy on ordering all the chicken skin skewers because they were low supply. (Only 1 skin skewer per table on this specific night.) If deciding between which chicken hearts, I enjoyed the SP and SPSP more than the regular ones. SP=special? SPSP=special^2? I prefer tomato>zucchini>shiitake. Of the sauces, yuzu is my favorite for its brightness. I think it pairs well with all the skewers. A little bit goes a long way. I tend to order one yuzu sauce to share for a table of 3 people.

I always recommend calling the restaurant to make reservations. For a 6:15pm weekday reservation, I called the same day (@ 5pm) to get a table for 3; I was lucky. On other occasions, I've booked a week in advance for a weekend dinner reservation. I've been here a total of 4 times in 18 months. The best time to call is during dinner service or an hour before the restaurant opens.

If deciding between counter or table seating, the counter is worth doing at least once.

My brother likes to write his name down when he visits Torigoya. He comes later in the evening when the 5- or 10-skewer sets are sold out and it's a la carte ordering. The wait is

name: Shin-Sen-Gumi Hakata Ramen - Little Tokyo
address: 132 S Central Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
If you're in LA, particularly in Little Tokyo, Shin-Sen-Gumi Hakata Ramen is an absolute must-try. This place originally launched its first bowls in LA, and it’s become a local favorite for good reason.

One of the unique aspects of Shin-Sen-Gumi is the customization they offer. You can tailor your ramen exactly to your taste with options for your preferred noodle firmness, broth richness, and additional toppings. Whether you like your noodles firm or soft, your broth light or rich, they've got you covered.

Everything about this place screams comfort and delivers perfectly. I adored the way each person could customize their ramen, and each of the toppings and elements were done to utter perfection. The servers and the overall relaxed atmosphere made for a lovely experience, I came away with a warm feeling.

BLAND RAMEN... it's more of a tourist trap than anything. Definitely wouldn't recommend this, my friends from out of state wanted to come here and I was fairly hesitant. Turns out I was right to be! I got the Yaki Ramen and it had the most top ramen taste ever. It had some meat which was okay but the sauce, noodles, and overall taste could not save this.

Service was actually pretty good, the servers were nice which is why I can't totally knock this place down. It's a good place for bigger groups. There's a long wait time so if you're living on the risky side and want to try this place you might be doubly disappointed. The place attracts lots of first-time  con-goers when AX or LACC are around so I would definitely stay away during those times.

Note: There's NO AC which sucks during the summer!

Ramen Ramen Ramen!!! This is now one of my favorite places. Be warned it does get packed from time to time. The atmosphere is lively. It's nice and clean. Staff is great. Very friendly and very attentive. Always there when needed to answer any questions and definitely kept our glasses full. The menu is simple. The food is really good. As you can tell, it's mostly Ramen (noodles). 9/10 And when you finish all your noodles, they ask you if you want a refill of noodles. That surprised us. Parking is rough. Best place to park is in the parking lot just south of the building. Parking voucher will get you 1 hour of free parking. I plan to visit again when I'm in the Little Tokyo area.

Employees are super friendly and awesome! The dandan ramen soup was awesome! You get to customize your own soup! For instance, from thickness to softness of the noodles or the thickness of the soup juice! Service was fast!

name: OOTORO LITTLE TOKYO
address: 232 E 2nd St E, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: When I tell you this was the best sushi I’ve ever had. LORD! The fish was so fresh and flavorful. The sake options were great and the service was great and the ambience was so intimate, and serene. Everyone there was so nice and I would definitely come here again. Come try them out it is soooo worth it!

Been coming here for years and their quality is always great and consistent. I get the premium or regular chirashi bowls and a few individual items like the amaebi and hotate. Love how they let us use the shrimp head to make miso soup or fried which are both delicious. Fair value and beautiful interior and spacious.

This place is delicious! We usually go to Sushi Gen, but didn't feel like standing in a long line. We found this spot in Google and we will definitely be back. We had their sushi platter for lunch and everything was melt in your mouth delicious! Red snapper was my favorite!! Definitely recommend this spot if you want a nice atmosphere, great service, and high end sushi!

It's been two years since my last visit, and I must say, the improvement in the food at this place is remarkable! 🥰 The chirashi bowl, in particular, left a lasting impression, and I can't wait to return. 🙌🏻 The generosity of their portions is commendable – the fish cuts are thick, the variety of fish is extensive, and all of this comes at a price of less than $30! It's simply too good to pass up. This recent experience has reignited my craving, and I'm eagerly anticipating my next visit. 🙊
really amazing nigiri, it melts in your mouth. hamachi (yellowtail) is my favorite here!! the restaurant is really pretty too, i love going here when in little tokyo

name: Sushi Gen
address: 422 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: The best sushi in LA. Fast service, freshest and best quality of fish. Highly recommend the toro (fatty tuna) and their fatty salmon. 10/10 for me. My mouth is still watering from the lunch I had today. I’m so happy I found this place. I recommend sitting at the bar ✨🍣🍣🍣🍣

Swooped in on a Friday lunch with my sister and friends and it was the best sashimi I’ve ever eaten. I ordered the sashimi deluxe and it was deliciously fresh and worth every penny! Quick and friendly service. I cannot wait to come back to try the other menu items!

Truly one of the best sushi spots in LA. The fish is fresh and the service is great. Although you have to wait a bit, the lunch special is pretty worth. Everything on the a La carte menu is a great choice too.

We came for the famous $23 lunch special and we’re not disappointed! The fish is extremely fresh and the portion of fish, rice, and appetizers was good for lunch. We also got the sushi deluxe combination to split. The sashimi lunch special was the best value item!

Come early to wait! We got in line around 10:20 on a Tuesday morning and got in with the first group to be seated (they open at 11 and the line is pretty long by 10:30. We found out that the a la carte menu is only served at the bar so if you want to to order off the normal menu, make sure you grab a table instead of sitting at the bar.

Genuinely disappointed in this place since the line was so long and people hyped it up. We lined up right at 10:30am and got in the 2nd group. My husband got the premium chirashi and I got the deluxe sushi set with salmon skin salad and mozuku. The salad was alright, looked better than it tasted. The mozuku was really sour and vinegary which i wasnt a fan of.

The deluxe sushi set was such a let down though, some of rolls were so basic (cucumber rolls?!) And it just didnt taste like what a deluxe set would be. Maybe i ordered the wrong thing but my husbands chirashi was just "okay" as well.

The place is also very old and could use a reno.

Also to top it off a crazy man was running around naked while we were waiting for the restaurant to be open. Not their fault obviously but an interesting experience to start the morning lol.

name: KAMINARI GYOZA BAR
address: 323 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: The crispy pan fried gyoza was delicious. Very close to my favorite restaurant in Kyoto. The gyoza soup was pretty tasty as well. Highly recommended!

Perfect perfect perfeccctttt thin wrappers, crisp pan fry, delicious filling.
Service was very attentive, clean, good music, will be my go to dumpling spot.

My husband heard this place a few month ago so we finally went to check.
We thought it’s only take out only but they slowly opened dine in.
We wanted to eat fresh made hot GYOZA so we ate there. It’s pretty good.

Nice staff 👍
Friendly. Parking maybe challenge but normally public parking every where in little Tokyo.

I visited this place for the first time and I had a great customer service experience. Even though I got the Bento box for lunch, I thought it had so much flavor and was perfect for a quick lunch bite. The staff was very quick in getting out the food.

The quality of the food is great. Everything is freshly made. They have a good assortment of fillings for the gyozas and different ways of having them cooked. They didn't take long to cook them and bring them to the table. The only thing is that the place is a bit tight. When I went, the high tables at the front of the restaurant were the only place open for seating. Each table only fits 8 customers at a time, and theres only 2 tables. So, at times, there would be a wait for seating.

name: Hama Sushi
address: 347 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: As a loyal fan of Japanese cuisine, I have to say I'm somewhat disappointed. Despite the high online ratings and my high expectations for the sashimi, the quality was quite average and nothing remarkable. Additionally, the restaurant does not allow photography. These photos of the dishes were taken discreetly. I don't understand why photography is prohibited—are they afraid the quality will be exposed?

I felt as if I was back in Japan. Great quality of food and amazing service. You can also ask for a full menu since not everything is there on the list to fill out. Do not hesitate to ask for suggestions. They make food pard by part, not everything at once. Hygiene is good. I was there twice and both times I had to wait, it was worth it. Chefs are very approaching too! I would go there again! Btw, you can also take away if needed.

Wonderful place to get top quality sushi and service. The owners are very inviting and friendly. Every dish was skillfully plated and presented. If you find yourself in the area or even far away stop by and you will not regret it.

My #1 go to sushi place. Hands down.
Unless I feel like just filling myself with sushi, if I want legit sushi, this is the place. Never disappointed. Chefs are so kind and vibe inside is so amazing

You might have to wait hr or two, but it is definitely worth the wait
Their Mackerel is my favorite too.

They have small menu but have exactly what I need.

Always thank you guys, and will support this place 100%
Please dont change!!

I love the atmosphere here. It was like sitting in a cozy sushi bar in Tokyo. However the sushi taste is not my favorite. Scallop was too  cold to be served. Sea urchin tasted creamy but the seaweed overwhelmed the flavor. Sweet shrimp was ok. If you like ankimo you have to ask, it is not in the menu but they have it.

name: Sushi Enya Little Tokyo
address: 343 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Authentic Japanese sushi at finest quality. This place serves sushi prepared at high-end style.  Everything will feel perfectly enjoyable.  Hence, they do use a bit of yuzu, but it makes the sushi a bit more unique and stylish.
The roles are great, and prepared in the right size for a bite.  It is size also the kids can enjoy easily.
Hence, the price point is not in the lower end. But the quality justifies it.

Came here for dinner in a group of 7 on a Friday night. We had to wait for an hour to get seated since we had a large group with no reservation. Indoor seating only. They have a omakase option but we all opted for a la carte. I had a chirashi bowl which was quite filling and had a lot of fish. I got green tea which came with free refills. Service was friendly and there are gendered restrooms in the back. Metered street parking. Credit cards accepted. It’s a classy spot to eat high quality fish.

This is the Little Tokyo outlet of Sushi Enya. The place is on the same street as the popular ramen place. We orders the 18 piece sashimi set  twice and the chef was thoughtful enough to put different fish slices on the two orders. We also tried their specialty eel roll which is served on a very long dish since eels are long? Quality of the fish are quite high and attention to details are there. There are not many tables so it gets crowded. Usually there is a wait so suggest to arrive early (5PM) or use table reservations. They have a cancellation fee if you make table reservation. There is no parking on site so you have paid street parking or paid parking structure near by.

Very disappointed.  I’d eaten here a few years ago and it was top notch.  Unfortunately, this latest visit was very mediocre.  Edamame was unsalted and bland.  Sushi fell apart and the squid was tough.   The shrimp was pretty good though.
This place was incredible! The service was extremely quick and the quality of the fish was very fresh. Everything was delicious, & everyone was so friendly. Will definitely be back.

name: Kura Revolving Sushi Bar
address: 333 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Love coming here but be ready for a wait. When you arrive, head inside and place your name on the waiting list (I have seen the queue in the high 50s) and then walk around the mall.

Once it is your turn, you are quickly seated and drink orders taken. A few minutes later, your water is delivered by a robot!!!!

There are premade sushi rolls that come around on a conveyor. But you can also order ramen, specialty rolls and deserts. These arrive on a second conveyor.

Once you are done eating, you can check out on the touch pad and pay with your phone or with your waitress.
Feels like japan. Very good sushi and fast service. Plus you get a reward for every 15 plates😃.

We had an incredible experience at Kura Revolving Sushi Bar in Little Tokyo! This place blends traditional sushi with modern technology for a fun dining experience. Go there asap and register for a table. We had to wait for a little less than 30 minutes but as the evening progressed, waiting times rose. It's first come, first served place. No reservations. But absolutely worth the wait.

The revolving sushi concept is engaging and efficient. Plates of fresh sushi glide by on a conveyor belt, ready to be grabbed. The touch screen at the table makes it easy to order additional items if needed. (Hack: you can order any sushi on the belt via the touch screen!)

The variety of sushi and Japanese dishes is impressive. From classic nigiri and sashimi to unique rolls and hot dishes like ramen and tempura, there’s really something for everyone.

The atmosphere is casual and fun, perfect for families and groups of friends. The staff is friendly and attentive, ensuring smooth service even during busy times. The rewards system, where you earn prizes by collecting empty plates, adds a playful touch. You can go for gold with the little toy lottery.

If you’re in LA, go to Little Tokyo and please don’t miss Kura Revolving Sushi Bar. It's a must-visit for sushi lovers and anyone looking for an interactive meal. Highly recommended!

Looking for a fun, tasty, sparky, lively, and happening Sushi Garden? Look No Further!! 9.5/10 — my favorites were also other people’s favorites, and the short wait for new bites was exhilarating!! Coming back MOST DEFINITELY!

Not quite bucket list, we'll call it practice for the real thing.  I keep saying I'm going to go to Japan and do a Soranews style review of the 3 major kaitenzushi restaurants, Kura being one of them.  Even on a Monday afternoon it was bustling, but I was able to get a seat quickly (solo life).  It almost fried my brain, so many choices, options I have never seen or heard of.  I had to stop myself from going crazy and tried to limit to nigiri I can't order back home in the crooked letter.  It's been a really long time since I was last at a kaitenzushi restaurant and things have changed.  COVID and cleanliness killed the open bar conveyor style I was used to.  The capsules for the plates were tricky, and I had a hard time getting the plate out even after my lesson from the staff.  I powered through though, cause I still spent almost $50 just on myself.  They also have a waiter robit, which they only kinda use lol.  I would see staff snag the drinks off and deliver them personally and send the robot back to the kitchen.  It was still cool to see, being my first experience in the wild.  Had the engineer in me nerding out a little.  If you don't see what you want you can order from a monitor above your seat and they'll bring it out or it'll arrive on the top belt.  You can also pay using this as well.  It tallies up your plates(they all cost $3.75) when you drop them in the slot.  I did forget I wanted a gotcha capsule, so disappointed in myself.  Glad I don't have these locally, I'd need another job to afford my eating habits.  Hoping next time I visit one it'll actually be in Japan.

name: Japanese Village Plaza
address: 335 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Walking through the area feels like a mini escape to Japan, right in the heart of LA.

The variety of shops and restaurants is impressive, catering to a range of tastes and interests. I particularly enjoyed browsing the unique selection of goods at the specialty stores, which offer everything from traditional crafts to modern Japanese pop culture items.

The dining options are excellent, with a good mix of authentic Japanese cuisine and fusion dishes.

While the village can get quite crowded, especially on weekends, the overall experience is worth it. It's a great spot for a casual outing with friends or family, and there's always something new to discover with each visit.

Overall, the Japanese Village is a lovely place to explore and enjoy a taste of Japanese culture in Los Angeles. I look forward to returning and trying more of what it has to offer.

Lots of little Japan stores and restaurants to go to but it's busy here during the weekend. The weekdays is better to visit as there won't be lines to wait to get into the restaurant or the shops and bakeries.  I liked it here during the weekends to get the treats I wanted without the long wait. Lots to see for trinkets and anime stuff. The prices here are a little higher than most places you would get  from other outside stores but good to visit.

Fun place to visit with some Japan vibes.

They got some interesting shops and restaurants. They got some Japanese merchandises that I would purchase as an anime fan.

They have a Japanese-American museum if you feel like getting a little history lesson as well.

I would bring my kids here to enjoy the vibes.

You will love it here if you are a fan of Japanese culture. Anime, Blindbox, Gashapon, Ramen, Sanrio, Shabu-Shabu, Sushi, Takoyaki, Taiyaki, etc! Come early so you can see every store and cap the evening with dinner. Parking is connected to the plaza and the max was $18.

The only downside is no public toilets. For a country who is known for the best toilets, tourists are missing out on that experience. Bathrooms are at the restaurants but only available to the patrons.

I suggest Toto set up a shop there to serve both an experience and sales opportunity.
I don’t know about you but most ppl who come back from a Japan visit will mention the toilets.

Worth it and would come again.

There are so many awesome shops here.  There are lots of fun trinkets to get, there is good food and lots of other goodies too.  Very enjoyable time and thankful they put everything so close together.

name: Aloha Cafe
address: 410 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: For delicious Hawaiian food, this is the place to go to in LA.   Everything is good, especially the Kalbi beef and chicken.  The charsiu is sweet and yummy 😋.  Highly recommended if you are in the mood for some delicious Hawaiian food!!

We got a loco Moco and their special BBQ ribs, both were really good and the portion are HUGE. It was enough for us to eat the leftovers for dinner too lol. We also ordered a side of spam musubi, the sauce on the spam was sweet and savory, tastes very good with the rice. Would definitely recommend!

Finding Aloha Cafe was a godsend for our wedding. Myy husband and I had dreamed of having Hawaiian mix plate food for our wedding. After some time searching we finally found Aloha Cafe and scheduled a tasting with Jennifer. The variety of dishes she offered were all delicious and exactly what we were looking for. Although AC couldn't offer full service catering, we hired them for our wedding appetizers (spam musubi!) and buffet food. The menu included green salad, mac salad, white rice, kalbi ribs, teriyaki salmon, and teriyaki chicken.

I can't express enough how helpful and involved Jennifer was throughout the process. She was very generous and proactive in helping us source things like banana leaves, bamboo plates, utensils, bulk dry foods, etc. The banana leaves were a huge part of our wedding design (we laid them on the guest tables with the appetizers on top in an ode to Filipino style "kamayan.") Jennifer was mindful of our guests with dietary restrictions and created vegan mix plates and musubis for them. One of our guests couldn't have pork so she made a special chicken musubi just for her! She also took the time to ensure that everything was dropped off, set up, and served properly. Our guests enjoyed their meals, which was a different experience from regular wedding food. My only regret is not having eaten more!

Aside from catering, the restaurant itself is top notch. Delicious food and amazing service. LA is lucky to have a gem that is Aloha Cafe!

As someone who just moved here and have been craving my home food! Ugh thank you! Loco Moco was so good and I always judge places when I try their musubis and yall are the first place in the mainland to actually make it like us! Mahalo 🌺

The quality is always super consistent and delicious! I have yet to find a place that has Hawaiian food that comes in such a huge portion, that is this high quality and for this price!
I've seen their kitchen and can confirm that everything, down to the sauces and dressings are made IN HOUSE. They slice and cut the chicken. It's super impressive and not very common anymore
It's rare to find any place in LA that isn't over $20 a person anymore, but definitely not a place where they legitimately make everything from scratch.
I definitely recommend the KB combo plate with fried rice, spam musubi and the loco moco plate.
The hours are the only reason I don't come literally all the time, but it's super privately owned and TOTALLY worth the wait.
Super psyched to get food for my baby shower from there.
Catering and pick up catering prices are also super reasonable too!

name: Pasta e Pasta by Allegro
address: 432 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: I love this place! I love the vibe. I've been here a few times. The wait, time varies, including the # of people you have for dine-in. this place is small but accommodating. Menu is simple and straightforward. Pasta is cooked to perfection.

This restaurant is tucked away from the busy part of Little Tokyo. We walked in at 6:30pm on a Thursday and were seated immediately. We came here for the famous uni pasta and mentai japanese cream pasta. Both were creamy, rich, and filled with umami. The mentai japanese cream one was slightly more fishy than the uni one. Can we talk about the portion sizes? Each plate of pasta was huge! Great value for the price.

All pastas come with complementary sad and bread. Save some of the bread to soak up all the pasta sauce!

Pasta e Pasta by Allegro offers a delightful atmosphere with excellent service. The waitress was notably helpful. The menu features a good variety, and our choices, the carbonara pasta and Mentai Japanese cream, were flavorful, creamy, and rich. The dishes were of high quality with generous portion sizes. I highly recommend this place.

Rare, Japanese-style pasta. All we ordered were really great. Carbonara was really creamy and rich taste. Mentaiko pasta was my favorite, with nice flavor of seafood.
I highly recommend for people who miss Japanese taste!

Super unique japanese-italian fusion place in Little Tokyo! Parking was easy as there was a parking lot that was free (maybe on weekends only)! The wait wasnt too bad. Waited no more than 20 minutes for a party of 5. Very surprising considering how small this place is.

The bacon and mushroom pasta was great! Hoever i do think that the bacon could be a little more crispy to add flavor and texture. You also get a free salad and bread.

Our server Vincent was awesome!

name: Orochon Ramen
address: 123 Astronaut Ellison S Onizuka St #303, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Someone recommended this place for lunch and let me say: I was wowed. It's hidden, it's small, the prices are great and I really enjoyed how customizable it was. It was 8 of us and the bill came to 120 granted only 6 got ramens and most stuck to water but the portions are huge! And they have a variety of spice levels to choose from.

Big Portions, Customized Bowls of Ramen... 7 levels of Spice of Soup Broth ranging from no spice, mild to extra extra spicy, Choice of Miso, Soy or Salt; Choice of Vegetarian or Pork Broth. Service and cooking time was fast. Famous for the Spicy Broth Challenge, wall of fame. Very Affordable, Quality Japanese Fast Food

Very flavorful ramen. I got the extreme 1 special ramen, and it was spicy but not that bad for someone who typically eats habaneros.  Great value, nice place. Will 100 percent be back for ramen. So far, the best I've found in DTLA. Located upstairs inside the center of the complex.

Stopped by here after shopping awhile, we were seated and served pretty quickly. Ordering was simple, and you are given a giant serving for the price, which is great. The presentation was pretty messy though, but it was really filling and tasty. Definitely want to come back and try it with more toppings. 😋
Tasty ramen. There are 3 broth choices miso, soy, or salt based. I got the soy and it was perfect. Hefty portion. Parking garage in plaza and steer parking.

name: Hakata Ikkousha Tonkotsu Ramen Little Tokyo
address: 368 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
My family and I visited Hakata Ikkousha Tonkotsu Ramen in Little Tokyo L.A., & as avid foodies from Oregon, we were excited to try a new spot in the city. From the moment we walked in, the staff were exceptionally friendly and helpful, guiding us through the menu and making recommendations since it was our first visit.

The food exceeded our expectations. The ramen was rich and flavorful, perfectly cooked. The broth had a deep, savory taste that made each bite incredibly satisfying. We also tried a few appetizers, which were equally impressive.

Overall, the dining experience was fantastic, earning a solid 10/10 from us. We can’t wait to return and explore more items on the menu. If you’re in Little Tokyo, we highly recommend stopping by.

I think this place is overrated for it's ramen. I got the "#1 best seller" tonkatsu ramen with everything. I was very disappointed. First, my egg was over cooked and wasn't presented like all the eggs seen in other photos. Second, the overall flavor of the ramen wasn't as expected, it was dull and lackluster. Third, the noodles felt cheap given that it costs an extra $2 to upgrade to premium noodles. I've had much better ramen at other places and don't recommend this place. Service wise, there's a form to fill out when placing an order which is convenient but overall service is lacking. I also tried the karage and it was good, but I expected better from this ramen house that supposedly serves authentic, premium ramen.

Extremely disappointed!!!  Gyoza were absolute grease-balls!  Tasted like greasy hamburgers. Gross! Worst gyoza I’ve ever had.  Tonkatsu ramen flavorless. Ugh.  And the waitress ignored our topping selection and simply added everything.  So disappointed!

A coworker recommended this place for the Fried Chicken, but everything here is great!

Easily one of the best Ramen spots in Little Tokyo. We got in at 5:30, wrote down our orders, and were served quickly. I had the Black Devil ramen, very rich, spicy and flavorful. We went premium for toppings and it is the perfect amount. The atmosphere is pretty comfortable but fast paced, however we did not feel rushed. Can't wait to come back here and try more!

I have been a loyal customer for over 7 years. No place is better than Hakata Ikkousha. The ramen with everything toping is a must. You don’t need to think which toping should you get, because you will get EVERYTHING. Dont forget the stamp card!

name: Marukai Market
address: 123 Astronaut Ellison S Onizuka St #105, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: There are so many shops.  This place was great.  This is always a go-to when we are visiting.  Love the market gor snacks.  The bookstore has so much in it.  There are plenty of other great stores too, and then there are the vendors too.  It's a great find and I recommend you go there when you are in the area.

Marukai feels exactly like a grocery store in Japan. They have it down with the daily fresh sushi and rolls, signage, and employees that will greet you in Japanese.

I had to visit a couple of times before I felt comfortable walking around the store to and figure out what I wanted. It can feel like you’re going in circles cause you are, but the layout does make sense after a few visits.

Sushi and bento boxes are 20% off after 7PM.
Parking is free with $25 purchase for up to 1 hour.
Personal checks are no longer accepted at checkout.
Alcohol sales end at 9PM.

They have a self check out and a regular check out, and microwaves by the exit to heat up meals.

You can get all kinds of specialty groceries, frozen food, Japanese snacks and fresh produce here. The price points are similar to that of a Ralphs or Vons.

Great selection of Japanese products from Japan and embodying Japanese culture. Picked up a few snacks to go. Area is busy at all hours. Great diversity in snacks, produce, and home goods. There is plenty of English translation and labeling to help understand what products are.

Sushi!! Anime stuff!! Snacks!! Drinks!! Avocados & vegetables!! Yakiniku meats!! Much more!! So convenient fairly clean & fresh!! Best atmosphere small building but not as big as one in Gardena (Artesia Blvd) location!! Wow!! The service is great!! Picking items what to eat; what to drink. My plan goes well. Busy shopping I’ve ever experienced!! I haven’t visited in Little Tokyo forever!! Happy as always!! Everyone must visit Tokyo Central to go shopping have fun commicate each other get involved with new items!! That’s about it!!

Every time we come to Little Tokyo, Marukai Market is a must stop. We always find something new and interesting to try. There are so many great things here that you simply cannot go just once. The sushi quality is outstanding, my personal favorite is the Toro Bowl with a Melon Calpico. 😊

Besides the large selection of food to-go and beverages, they have an extensive selection of vegetables, fruits and Japanese necessities. You can get everything you need here, and they validate parking, which is very helpful when parking in the Weller court. Love this place, will be back soon!

name: Far Bar
address: 347 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Thoroughly enjoyed Far Bar’s happy hour, which runs from 3-7pm Monday to Friday, and all day Monday. Best value play is the Burger Special ($13), which includes fries and a Sapporo or soda.

Wings are also excellent. Will try their shrimp tacos next! Service is awesome and the vibes are casual yet with a classy decor (especially outside). Love this historic spot!

Great choice for some late night food and drinks in Little Tokyo. Casual vibes, nice ambience. Tried the Far Bar roll, fish seemed fresh and it packed a punch with the flavor and spice. Service was attentive, food came quick, and staff was knowledgeable/careful of food allergies. Prices weren’t decent too. Overall would recommend.

Awesome wasabi fries. Location is pretty cool too, right in front of Miyako Hotel. Staff is knowledgeable with their bourbon. I've had Pappy 23, Heaven Hill 20, Parker's Heritage 24 years, Stagg Jr Batch 17, Old Fitz 11, and GTS 142 proof. Good shot prices, real pour size as well.
One of the best bars in the city. Their Tokyo Old Fashioned is excellent, and their food is great as well. I’ve tried the Bacon Fried Rice, Wasabi fries and sushi.

Them ming wings is ridonkulous.

Great service, fantastic drinks and sake selection. Can’t wait to come back and try more of the food!

name: Men Oh Tokushima Ramen
address: 456 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Took the A line from work. Subway drops you off on the other side of Honda Plaza. Great ramen really enjoyed the amount of noodles and two kinds of pork; sliced and belly. The broth was excellent and comforting. I added chili sauce and an order of gyoza and a Sapporo. $17 for a bowl of Tokushima Ramen. Very delicious.
Recommended as one of the best ramen in town by TimeOut, I was a bit disappointed. The broth was very good but felt the pork could be better.

Affordable, chill, and super tasty ramen.
Ate here two days of my trip to LA and loved it.
The Tokushima Ramen was outstanding, with pork slices and pork belly intermingled with perfectly cooked noodles. The broth, however, was the best part--I only wish there was more!
Had higher expectations because of the reviews online, but I thought the broth was a little bland. Got the tokushima ramen. Also did not love how the pork was made.

name: Tsukemen Aizen
address: 232 E 2nd St Suite B, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: This restaurant took me back to when I was in Japan trying my first tsukemen. We both ordered a regular original and the noodles are soft and fresh and the broth is flavourful and thick. We were extremely full when we were done. The staff were really nice and welcoming. We paid around d $37 for everything.

We ordered both a small and a regular tsukemen DX, and they were absolutely delicious. The small portion size was just perfect for me. A complimentary refreshment drink they offer at the end of our meal was a lovely touch! The interior of the place is modern and cozy. Loved everything about this place and will definitely be coming back. Highly recommend!

EXCELLENT SERVICE ! Incredibly accommodating, they were able to serve my party of 22, great communication and food came in a timely manner. The food was fine and so was the seating area, spacious enough for my group to be seated close to each other.

The Tsukemen is $14 for Original. The noodle portion is small for a guy, get the Regular one at least if you are a dude. Extra noodle is $2.50.
The dipping soup is lighter in texture than what I am used to, but it is fine. The soup base is on the saltier side but still enjoyable.
Overall I still think it is a legit taste.

The servers are pretty attentive. They’ll serve the hot stone midway through your meal to keep your broth nice and hot. I will request for a dashi broth at in the end to finish up the soup base.

Be warned parking in Little Tokyo is a bit of a circus.

Also a notable art is the little art piece dangling from the ceiling.

We ordered the tsukumen deluxe large and the portion was massive! The noodles were al dente, the broth delicious without being too heavy and the egg was runny and full of flavor. Service was also top notch. Will definitely be back!

name: Spitz - Little Tokyo Restaurant & Bar - Mediterranean Food and More
address: 371 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
I got lucky with the parking out front, but not inside because of their BOGO soft opening deal. It was packed with a small line to order. I had takeout, so forgive the togo containers in the photos.

I got the Street Cart Wrap with beef and lamb, as well as the Berliner Bowl with chicken and quinoa.  I ate nearly a 1/3 of the bowl and 1/2 the wrap.  The flavors were very addictive. This was a comfort food I never knew I needed.  Such freshness and I loved the texture of all the ingredients in the salad. The berliner sauce had a pleasant tang to it.  The Wrap had a garlic aioli that I wish I had more to dunk with. Definitely worth checking out.

A delightful little spot that serves three kinds of sangrias (I tried the peach) but has also a full selection of hard liquor for the grownups. There's seating at the bar and also general inside seating as well. With tons of natural lighting it is as its patrons, quiet and thoughtful. A peaceful little pocket world self-contained, a tick away from the noise, the relentless sounds of hustle & flow, just right outside its closed door. You could write here, alone on your laptop creating it just observing the every day ordinariness of nice people living their best lives, have a real conversation with another person you cared about, maybe even a stranger, someone new (you may one day grow to care very much about), who initially wanted to know only what that wonderful looking salad you were having was...

Or just sit quietly with no need of words simply enjoying good food, the comforting solitude of your own company and the silence, having no external interaction at all. I forget that sometimes; how nice it is to be still, completely indulgent of the serenity found only in silence. You can do that here. If you want.

I had a delicious 'Donner' salad, long island ice tea and the most splendid conversation since like I just said, I forget, I mean A Lot, I confess, how nice it is to be silent ;o)

This is one of what I hope will be many little gems here in DTLA I get to discover. I will most certainly be back. If you stop in ask for Shona, she's the other very attractive mixologist behind the bar.

Modern take on Mediterranean food. I got a Berliner wrap, and I wish there was more meat. The wrap itself is substantial but it felt small eating it all. I was hoping for it to be bigger because whenever I make a wrap with other Mediterranean joints, my wrap is huge and overflowing with food for a fraction of a price that they sell here at Spitz.

The cashier was nice and the atmosphere is intimate. A little too dark for my liking though. It almost looks closed from the outside.

This is a good meet up joint though.

The Berliner was my favorite. Didn’t like the Doner basket as much as the Berliner but it was still filling for the price. The Doner basket has everything in it and I thought it’d be more my speed but was just ok. Gives me lunch vibes or something quick vibes. Bartender was delightful, food came out fast and feels healthy. The beef-lamb meat is flavorful. Didn’t like the falafel. Strong and unique drinks. I’d recommend this place for a quick bite. $15 Flat rate parking garage near by. They should validate parking

First time here. My son and I had lunch. Cooks and waiters were friendly, the place was clean, love that they have self serve water and doggie bag items available++ and the food was delicious!
Had the Remix bowl with beef and lamb; their lemon dressing sauce was amazing! My son had the Berliner bowl They had three different sangrias available my son had the white sangria and he said it was good.
Nice music, people, and space to eat outside if you like.

name: Izakaya BIZAN
address: 333 S Alameda St #314, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews: Went here for fathers day with my kids. My daughter recommend ed this restaurant and she did a great job. The Sushi was super fresh and some of the best I have ever had, and I have had a lot. Highly recommend

Food was pretty good. They serve high quality sashimi if you are willing to pay the premium. Great place to impress, but no longer as lively as it was before when it was still Honda Ya. I was there during lunch, so considering it's an Izakaya maybe it picks up at night.

Best izakaya experience we've had in the states. The yakitori was fantastic, and our waiter suggested sashimi was delicious. Our waiter Shoya was awesome and made sure our group had a great time.  We'll definitely come again in the future
A little pricy, but not much considering its location. Absolutely delicious authentic cuisine tucked away at the top of the Galleria. Love the inside. Wonderful service too

Izakaya Bizan is located inside the Little Tokyo Shopping Center, on the 3rd floor. One piece of advice for fellow diners: If you prefer a regular table, it's best to make a reservation in advance. However, if you arrive on the day without one, consider yourself lucky as you might get a chance to sit at the sushi bar.

The Japanese yakitori at Izakaya Bizan was simply delicious. The flavors of the skewered and grilled meats were perfectly balanced, making it a delightful culinary experience. Each bite was a burst of umami goodness, and I couldn't help but try several different varieties.

For our meal, I ordered the monkfish liver as a starter, and it was a delectable choice. Creamy, rich, and delicately flavored. As for the main course, I went with the Chirashi bowl, and it did not disappoint. The fresh assortment of fish and toppings over a bed of perfectly seasoned sushi rice was a delight for both the eyes and the palate. My friend opted for the poke bowl as the main course, and they were equally delighted.

To complement our meal, we decided to try the Green Tea Plum Wine. It was an intriguing choice with a unique and captivating taste that perfectly complemented the dishes we had ordered.

name: Otomisan Restaurant
address: 2506 1/2, 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90033, USA
reviews: Nothing fancy, home style historic Japanese restaurant. Very small and quant around four to five booths and around 6 seats and counter. Food is good and well prepared but very basic. Given the size and popularity expect a short wait. Service is pleasant and efficient. Lots of locals eat here.  Street parking only.

I just don’t get the magic about this restaurant, we tried 3 times to get in for this mediocre dinner, the first 2 times the waiting is too long and they close at 8pm.

I thought it must be good, but I was so wrong.
The green tea and oolong tea and the natto it’s not even house made, they got them from supermarket—this is the first time in a Japanese restaurant I saw somebody take out bottle drinks from fridge and serve to us lmao.

And for the salmon and spicy chicken bowl we ordered, it’s nothing special, like I can get them from anyother Japanese restaurant.the only thing I like about this restaurant maybe it’s the atmosphere, like a Japanese old house kitchen.

I have to mention that this area is not a safe area, and I don’t think it worth the wait.

First the atmosphere: it's a cute, well put together little Japanese restaurant. Walls line with art and photos. You can read the history of the place as you eat. Dining tables and a bar to sit and enjoy a meal.

Second, the food: impeccable food displayed on nice plates. Large chunks of fish in the sushi rolls. Spicy tuna and salmon roll had a smooth texture and world-class taste. I did not use soy sauce or because the fish was amazing by itself. This alone will bring me back. I ordered a combo with beef teriyaki and pork cutlet. The pork cutlet was succulent. Pick it up with chopsticks and marvel at the juiced flow. The crust had standalone flavor that I might use as a topping by itself if that were an option. The beef was cooked to perfection. The yeriyaki sauce had a unique taste to it. Came with soup and salad. Miso is a simple dish that this establishment has perfected. The salad was a standard side salad with ginger dressing. Great way to cleanse the palatte. Tempura was also served, and it was again a world-class dish. Fresh tasting veggies and two healthy shrimp.

Lastly, the service:the older woman who was there was a gem, and this review is not about her. This review is about the young, inexperienced waitress. I don't think she has enough experience to be serving folks, so this may not be the best place for her to learn. This establishment is the longest running japanese restaurant in Los Angeles. That comes with a heavy burden. The young waitress was not warm or inviting. These two traits are set in stone within japanese culture. As the older woman tried coaching the younger, she younger woman gave dirty looks and rolled her eyes. She seemed uninterested and worse than that, unwilling to learn from her elder. I will be back at some point and hope to see how her journey is going.

Overall, you will be satisfied here. Please come one and all to a modern marvel of japanese cuisine in the greater Los Angeles area.

Great history and food.  Very impressive tempura and curry, and of course the sashimi was super fresh. I do miss AOI, so the home estylen cooking here was a real rad treat. I loved it, we came pretty early and on a weekday as you must do because it gets filled up so fast!!  So glad we made the effort because it had been on our list so long and it didn't disappoint

Purely for charm and LA history, Otomisan is outstanding. The oldest continuously operating Japanese restaurant in the city, there's certainly a retro feel to this place that can't be replicated.

Ever since a few well-received profiles (Vice, PBS, etc), Otomisan has experienced a burst in popularity. On Saturday, we arrived at 11:30am, which is when they opened, and already all three booths were taken. Our party of four sat at the counter, which honestly might have been the reason we had such swift service.

The owner is SUPER nice and even though she was obviously totally overwhelmed with a long waiting list and a bunch of takeout orders, she handled everything with a smile and didn't rush anyone out.

The food is exactly like what I had when I ate at my friends' parents' or grandparents' houses who were Japanese American, so this meal was a lovely hit of nostalgia.

Highly recommend the katsu, teriyaki, tempura, edamame, and salmon roll.

name: Takami Sushi & Robata Restaurant
address: 811 Wilshire Blvd #2100, Los Angeles, CA 90017, USA
reviews:
Rooftop bar and sushi restaurant, can't  eat this dynamic duo combination. Valet parking was easy, had to drive through the alley and $12 fee covered until 3a for those that want to dine and then party after. I had reservations and had to wait 5-10 minutes, however was completely fine since there is a full bar in the reception area. Ambiance was nice, dimly lit so you can enjoy the views of the LA skyline. Had a table outside, which was perfect and already warm due to the various wall mounted heaters throughout. The restaurant has 3+ different kitchens for sushi, warm dishes and grilled foods, providing a versatile Japanese menu. The drinks were also amazing... Tokyo Mule, yes 2 please!!!
Appetizer and food came extremely quick, only wait time was on the drinks, which wasn't that long and definitely worth the wait.

We made a reservation but it turned out that wasn’t necessary as it’s not busy. But the atmosphere was nice and you could see the city from above. Our waiter was extremely nice. He was attentive and cheerful. The food was really good. My sashimi was very fresh and it’s the first time that I had fresh wasabi.

We sat outside to enjoy the view. I would recommend sitting outside if you want to take in the city life while having the freshest food.
Wonderful food and our waitress Megan was outstanding!!! Great service and so fun. On the 21st floor of a tall skyscraper and the views were wonderful.

Food was excellent, my friend and I were I. La for 2 days, and we were recommended this place. Drinks were pretty good as well, some of the service was a little slow, but my issue was the front telling us we couldn’t have a seat at a table because they had “a lot of reservations that night”. We sat in their lounge couch area, but not once during the about 1-1.5 hours while we were there were all tables full. We could have easily been sat at a 2 person table.

You are definitely paying for the view and good service. The views are gorgeous, especially if you have a reservation around sunset. Our server was very upbeat and kind.
To be honest, I expected the sushi to be better. It was just okay.. definitely not “high quality” sushi. But taking in the views and drinks are definitely a good way to spend time up here!

name: Sushi Takeda
address: 123 Astronaut Ellison S Onizuka St ste 307 3rd floor, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: This is a gem! I’m a big fan of Omakase sushi and this place did not disappoint. I highly recommend sitting at the bar. Service was impeccable, friendly, and always ready. Attention to detail was superb! I didn’t take any photos because they asked me to silence my phones (you can still take photos), but I wanted to be respectful and also focus on my taste buds and not my phone. Admittedly this place doesn’t look much from the outside (Weller Court could use some updates), but don’t be afraid to step inside. One suggestion for them is to have a sake pairing option as I am a sake lover. I did get their cold sake that ended up tasting wonderful, so I’m not complaining. As for price, I think it’s reasonable for an Omakase place like this. You’re really paying for the experience. Without drinks, I think it’s around $200 for a full course meal and tax/tip. Highly recommend!

Our children sent us off to this dinner date while they were out of town. What a great gift. We had a cold sake with melon notes and their homemade yuzu soda to go with their excellent nigiri omakase. We ordered repeats of the sawara, kawahagi and toro taku and also ordered anago on top of the omakase. We normally don't enjoy the tamagoyaki but their castella style tamagoyaki was so good. This nigiri omakase was the perfect amount but would like to try their signature omakase in the future.

Amazing meal and service. Sushi was phenomenal and every bite was better than the last. The beer selection was very interesting, the first beer on the list being the best. Free refills on ginger. A hidden gem on the third floor of a Little Tokyo mall. Very fun. Very cute. Would omakase again.
Very fresh sushi at good price. Authentic dishes and great service. Chef and sous chef was nice and receptive. Place a little hard to find.

Great omakase experience 👏 Chefs at the sushi counter were both very talented and friendly. I arrived late due to the heavy traffic but the staffs were accommodating and made sure we enjoy the most of the course. Sushi were very fresh, was told many of the fishes I enjoyed arrived fresh today from Japan. Nice and clean restaurant. Located on the 2nd floor of the plaza.

name: Bar Sawa
address: 111 S San Pedro St sawa, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Hidden away in the city of Los Angeles is this amazing bar that serves one of the tastiest omakase. Entering the bar, you see a bar top that seats approx 10-12 people, with a open kitchen vibe. My partner and I had a great time. The Sunday crew was very nice and attentive, engaging with the customers and making things fun! The selection of fish was amazing, definitely a different experience compared to other omakase establishments I've been to.

Parking was very easy since they provided easy simple instructions on their website :). Will definitely visit again on a Sunday 😊😊

Hidden gem for sure. This restaurant has been on my husband's list and he was so excited/hyped to try it out! Discovered it on Instagram and got us reservations for a party of 4.

The experience was impeccable. Our sushi chefs and bartenders were amazing. Service was exceptional. It was a 17 course Omasake and of course our husbands had to get the Japanese whiskey. Super impressed. Drinks were delicious. 5/5!

Somehow managed to book two seats on a workday night. Overall portion is small. Totally 17(I remember?) courses but both my husband and I are still feeling half full after the entire course. (And this is based on each of us had two cocktails) We went to yakitori afterward and had 5 skewers each of us. That’s how little portion the meal was…
Appetizer and the noodle dish was really good. Sushi wasn’t very impressive as a lot of the fish cuts are not the best cuts. $170 you can find better sushi somewhere else for better cuts of fish. Personally I don’t like the rice here. I think this place has potential but definitely has more aspect to improve on.

Bar Sawa offers artfully crafted sushi and cocktails served as an Omakase in a modern trendy environment.

To start off with the most important part the food and drink is definitely top notch. The sushi offerings are distinct. Not entirely traditional but offering some creative twists like smoke infusion without becoming gimmicky. Each course is beautifully crafted and plated. The fish was near perfect the rice was inconsistent and sometimes a little too dry or dense depending on the course.

Cocktails focus around Suntory brand offerings and lean heavily into traditional Japanese flavors like Yuzu and Matcha. Overall a fun and creative twist. The cocktail tasting menu allows you to pick 3 drinks the enjoy during your omakase or you can chose from wine and sake options. It would have been a bit better if they offered a cocktail tasting that was tailored to the courses served.

The restaurant itself definitely focuses on the trendy whiskey bar aesthetic and pulls it off very well. Each Omakase seats only 6 people so it keeps an intimate environment. Some of the logistics around entry are a little lacking. You enter the basement level by elevator and find yourself in a slightly awkward brightly lit waiting room off a long hallway. It feels more like hotel bar at first but thankfully once inside the environment is better.

Service was ok. The restaurant is very new and staff is obviously still training. The chef's  pull double duty as chef and waiter as is typical of an Omakase. Here however the waiters also serve as bartenders and oddly the hostess as well which makes things a little convoluted since one of them had to go to greet the next round of guests.

Overall it was a fun experience but doesn't quite live up to the best similarly priced Omakase experiences in LA. However I think there's a ton of potential for it to be one of the best as it is refined further. There is clearly a strong sense of quality and creativity that hasn't been fully realized in such a new restaurant that's still ramping up.

I'd definitely recommend a visit. Reservations are needed in advance and book fast. Parking available in the structure next door.
The staff was very friendly, the drink was good (yuzu sour?) and the food did not disappoint!

name: Redbird
address: 114 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: An amazing restaurant located close to Little Tokyo, this restaurant offers an elegant menu with high quality ingredients. The staff is amazing, the food was delicious, and the cocktails the perfect amount of alcohol in them. Definitely one of my top restaurants to recommend!

We hit up this spot for brunch inside a cool, old church, and honestly, it was awesome! The vibe was just as you'd expect - super chill and unique. Tried the pumpkin pancake, and it was bomb - tasty but not too sweet, with a nice kick from the pumpkin seeds. The beef dish was tender, flavorful, and just right. Definitely going back to check out dinner next time!

This was a fantastic meal.   Food was fresh and delicious.  Loved the menu and selections!   It is expensive but a great experience.  Would go again.

Atmosphere was really nice and enjoyable.  Potions were large for this type of restaurant.   It was slightly loud for those with hearing problems.

I can’t speak for dinner but for brunch this a top tier brunch spot. Everything was good and they’re really trying to push to give you the best food and service possible. They do something different with their mimosas, I’m not exactly sure they explained it to me but after a few I have forgotten just know they’re perfect. Don Flamenco grapefruit drink is also amazing. All the food was truly exceptional. The blueberry pancakes are huge ! The bacon is so smoky and perfect. The frittata and egg sandwich were both great also. I even posted a pic of the ice cubes cause they’re perfect 😂. Also the atmosphere with the service is just so fire. The roof opens up when it’s nice out. Such a dope vibe. You can’t miss if you come here. Highly recommended!!

Walking into Redbird Restaurant felt like stepping into a cozy culinary haven where every corner whispered promises of delightful flavors and unforgettable moments. From the moment we were greeted, the staff showered us with genuine warmth and impeccable service, setting the stage for an extraordinary dining adventure. Our taste buds were first seduced by the crudo, where the buttermilk sauce played a tantalizing role, leaving us craving more with each heavenly bite. The Chawanmushi was a revelation, a delightful surprise that made us wonder why it's not a staple on every menu. And oh, the black bass! It was like a love letter to seafood lovers, each forkful a symphony of tender, melt-in-your-mouth perfection, perfectly complemented by the earthy goodness of Brussels sprouts. Redbird is a sanctuary for food enthusiasts, a place where every dish tells a story.

P. S. I tried Casablanca coctail but didn’t like (I’m also not a coctail person)

name: Yuko Kitchen DTLA
address: 101 W 5th St, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews:
Beautifully set up place. Good vegan options. 2 of us shared a platter and a cherry tomatoes and garlic appetizer.
The cookies were good too. The green tea cookie was really tea forward,. I enjoyed it but not everyone who tasted it did :)

Like stepping through a portal from downtown L.A. into a serene plant filled garden, that happens to smell delicious. The atmosphere was charming.  The food was fantastic. The staff was friendly.  The overall experience was wonderful. If we find ourselves in the neighborhood again we will absolutely stop in.
Food is great and the inside is beautiful! I got udon and chicken karage 😊 All the plants are pretty and they also have cafe items such as tea and cookies.

This place is amazing. The only downside is the homeless and drug use all over the surrounding sidewalk areas. Overlooking that, since they can not do anything about that, the service is wonderful, the environment is beautiful, and the food is top knotch at a good price. Try the cookies!!!

I live out-of-state and was looking forward to trying this place out during my visit to DTLA. Exactly what I hoped for, everything was delicious and the environment is so charming and refreshing. Had a teriyaki chicken rice bowl and apple mint lemonade, then took a milk tea boba for the road. Loved it, and I’m looking forward to checking out the Wilshire location the next time I’m in LA :)

name: Little Tokyo Galleria
address: 333 S Alameda St, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews: Small mall but very spacious and you'd be surprised by all the stuff going on here. They don't really have a huge selection of clothing stores but they have cafes, restaurants, a market, beauty stores, stationary and cute stuff, karaoke and so on! Must go to, very unique mall experience and I think they have something for everyone at every budget.
Fun shops and restaurants plus a clean bathroom in a neighborhood where it is hard to find any at all. Easy parking to boot. This place deserves your business!

As 2 broke icons, we could only venture out into Little Tokyo to live out our FRUiTS dreams... Shoichi Aoki how we citrusly wish you were there to photograph us

Eating yummy cute foods and desserts, reading manga, checking out figurine/cosplay/merch stores, and just walking around the area was pretty much what we did.

It wuz indeed a berry fun day x3

Went to the Anniversary party for Harajuku Day which happens every three weeks ordinarily.
Harajuku Is cute but deadly and a bit expensive. Bring a full wallet! When done, go outside and buy some Taiyaki. Soo good!
This galleria has one of the coolest views over Arts District from their rooftop parking level. Sometimes there’s vegan sushi catered on the rooftop. Awesome!

name: Ramen Maruya
address: 104 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
This is a popular restaurant on social media, and I came to try it out of curiosity. The portion size of their signature ramen is astonishing, with an overwhelming amount of pork.
