Even as someone who loves ramen, I couldn't finish it—the portion is just too intimidating. Friendly tip: for those with an average appetite, three people could easily share one bowl.

The serving speed is fast, and both the tempura and fish skin salad are quite good. The sushi is very delicious.

Now, about the drawbacks of the signature ramen: the noodles seem to be the kind that are bought in bulk, with a very average texture. Additionally, the broth is extremely salty, to the point where it feels like they added salt without any consideration. Moreover, it's clear that the broth contains MSG, which is very disappointing.

Overall, this restaurant offers good value for money, and the prices aren't too high. There are always long lines, so if you're into trying out trending spots, you might want to check it out.

Hello! The Trekking Pawns here! We left so happy and stuffed! Arrived around 6:30 and the place was empty, which was a little concerning, but the place quickly filled over the next hour. We started with crispy fried chicken (very good) and simply salted edamame. The ramen was delicious but not as spicy as advertised. The sashimi was thickly sliced and delicious and came with three different lovely side dip! Also tried the snow crab rolls and it was very delicious. The bathrooms were usable but not the best.

This place was great! Service and atmosphere was wonderful. Very friendly staff and nice seating areas.
Tonkatsu ramen was super delicious and highly recommend if you're ever in Little Tokyo in Los Angeles area. Broth was a little creamy, but still tasty and chashu had very good texture and soft. Noodles also had good firmness and a bit on the thinner side.
10 out of 10 would go again!

This area is magical and if you are into Studio Ghibli and Anime; it's right up your alley. We gathered here with friends to enjoy great food and it did not disappoint.
I loved their Thai Iced tea and I ordered their large bento boxes with chicken katsu..It came with tempura, egg rolls, salad, tofu soup and California rolls. I couldn't finish everything..Definitely enough for two people.
I will come again. You have the entire village to wander around and shop with a full belly. It was fantastic.

Food was pretty good. Visiting from NYC with friends and I was surprised by the serving size of the katsu don. Definitely would get ramen over the katsu next time though, I sampled some of the broth from the group and it’s pretty tasty and hearty. The char siu was also very tasty

name: Little Tokyo
address: Little Tokyo, Los Angeles, CA, USA

name: Shabu-Shabu House
address: 127 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: This was my first time going to this place with my friend she recommended it and I like the place. It was very cozy. Very nice. We went to right before they were closing, but the food was still fresh. The only thing was that they will not let you share One combo was a lot of food so we had to get the double combo but other than that there was a lot of food left. The place is really nice and great for any occasion.

A revision of a long standing Shabu Shabu restaurant that was closed about a year ago.  It is now called Shabu House and although the sign on the wall says "Since 1991" the experience has more differences than similarities. The beef cut with a deli slicer is still present now in the rear of the restaurant in a glass display area. The horseshoe counter has been converted to have seating on both sides, increasing seating but appears to limit staff movement. The food has also been changed with the classic shabu shabu ingredients supplemented with more pan-asian hot pot offerings like fish balls, fish cake and potato and lunch offerings have been changed to include dishes like Korean-style ramen and kimchee fried rice.

The shabu shabu comes as a set with three tiers of pricing starting at 30 dollars which includes a vegetable and fish cake assortment and beef with the second tier adding shrimp and a possibly larger serving of beef. The 3rd tier is the most expensive and says it includes Wagyu beef. The serving of meat on the first tier was generous and filled a large tray. It was sliced paper thin and had decent marbling.

The transition of the horseshoe allows for more seating but makes the counter feel more cramped. The dish set up is made up of two trays with metal serving bowls. Shoyu, chili sauce, chili oil and ponzu sauce are included at the table as well as minced garlic and spring onions. Goma (sesame sauce) is provided in a small dish with the meal and was used up quickly. No ladles were provided and the grey foam from the cooking meat quickly built up and coated the food. A Chinese spoon was included and at attempt to remove the foam filled up the serving dishes on the vegetable plate over the course of the meal.

Service was attentive though seemed to go through waves of availability. On arriving at the restaurant it was unclear if you sat yourself or if the staff were supposed to seat you. Tablets are at every seating for staff free ordering. A tablet was positioned by the door but it was not working. Attempts to flag down staff after waiting for them to notice someone at the door took some time as they were running around bringing food to various stations.  Once I go a server's attention I was quickly seated and the food came immediately. Staff came to ask if I needed anything about 6 times over the course of the meal though did not appear to anticipate issues like running out of sauce. Checkout was at a counter at the front of the restaurant and after I was noticed standing at the counter a staff member came over quickly and took care of the bill.

Overall it is nice to have a Shabu Shabu Restaurant back in Little Tokyo Village Plaza. The price seems high but this is likely not the restaurant's fault considering the rapid gentrification of Little Tokyo. The service is earnest and friendly though appears to be experiencing some growing pains.

Seems to be under new ownership. There are some improvements and some things the same. All ordering is via tablets now. They converted the inside row to also seat customers. Haven’t eaten at the new place yet. Ate at the old place about 100 times so have high hopes the quality is being maintained. Disregard the old photo posts of out-of-date hours and menu. I just posted current pics from two weeks ago.

The first time I came here, it was 1994

Until now, it hasn’t changed and it still the same

The waiting is not as ling as before, maybe I came here on the weekdays

The income is still there serving the customer

The menu also is still the same like 30 years ago, except the price has increased $10

The Quality Beef is AWESOME!

Extremely RECOMMENDED!

*** Tip: bring cash and come very early to sign up on the waiting list as soon as it’s out.

Visited recently and arrived at opening time (5:30pm). To my surprise there was a waiting list 1.5 pages long already. They had a total of 3 sheets available to sign up, half of that amount was already taken before they even opened. I appreciate the guy (who calls you in to sit) letting us know the wait from this point was 1.5-2 hours. Arrived at 5:30pm and seated around 7:30pm and not any earlier. By the time we were seated names were half way down the 3rd sheet of paper.

Food - great just as I remembered it. Regular portion is 10 slices while Large is 15 slices. I love their ponzu sauce - wish I had a bottle for home use. Something to note: You are boiling your food in water. At other shabu shabu places they may have a mild kelp/seaweed type stock. People have a misconception mistaking it for Chinese hot pot where the liquid is super flavorful. This is not that. What makes this delicious are the delicate marbled pieces of beef and your choice of dipping sauces, ponzu and sesame. There are little condiment containers, I put a lot of garlic into my ponzu sauce. Yum!

They start preparing for the next round of eaters before the current group leaves. As they get closer to seating a group, he will call whoever’s name is written and ask for your entire parties order before hand. Other workers will start slicing the portions of meat arranging them neatly on individual plates, cover it with saran wrap, and place them into the fridge until you are seated. This helps to speed up the process so there is less wait time. As soon as a party leaves, their area is cleaned, a new pot and veggies were placed. He will call groups in and you are hopefully within ears reach or will be passed over. While their rules are strict, it makes sense considering the number of people needing to be served.

Parking - think typical downtown, metered parking and paid parking lots. I always park across the street in either the structure or the driveway directly next to it (on the left side) which is another parking area but outdoors.

The restaurant is very small and not good for large groups or parties with young kids/infants. All the seating is counter style, the only table I saw was a kids table no one was seated at. Great meal on a cool or rainy day! Next time I’d come earlier and would hangout in the area.

name: Yunomi Handroll
address: 806 E 3rd St #100, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews: Wowza! Been traveling for a month and this was the best food I’ve had during the trip. Absolutely delicious appetizers and hand rolls. Everything we ate was 10/10. They also have an exhaustive list of beers and sake. Will absolutely come back on my next visit to LA.

One of the best hand roll places in LA!

Hand roll chef Rachel makes our experience here memorable every time!!!

Ooo also get a rock shrimp tempura to start 🤤🤤🤤

(also posted on their Yelp page)
Yunomi can be compared to Kazu Nori because they make hand rolls.

Food is good. Service is ok. Parking sucks. Ambiance is great.

Yunomi has a small-ish space in side because the seats are along the bar around the kitchen where they make drinks and hand rolls. They have two bathrooms in the back, but the hand washing station is outside the bathrooms. My party of three had to wait about 10-15 minutes even on a week day night.

I personally had five hand rolls and still wasn't completely full. The guy who greeted us when we got seated knew it was our first time there, but he said nothing except the menu is obtained by scanning the QR code on the table. It was good thing I checked out the menu from photos posted online because he came back really quickly to take our orders.

I think the hand roll sets are a cool way to try different fish, but the blue crab and negi toro and unagi are probably the better ones to try. They're more expensive - the negi toro is $11 lol.

There's free parking in the streets, but it took me 30 minutes to finally find a spot and I still had to walk 7 minutes to the restaurant. At least you can get Salt & Straw for dessert across the street.
I used to willingly drive 30 minutes to eat here, but unfortunately the quality of the food has gone down. It is no longer worth a 30 minute drive. The entire staff changed and so has the vibes.

Delicious handrolls with lots of options for “sets” and “a la carte” selection. Each fish option has a customizable “spicy or regular” and seaweed paper or soy paper.
I love love looooved their Yunomi roll which has perfect texture and lots of flavor.
They have an impressive selection of Japanese beer including a matcha ipa and plenty of sake options by the bottle or single serve.

Will definitely come back!

name: Aizen (in Bizen Restaurant)
address: 232 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews:
Went there for DineLA and cannot recommend this place enough! To begin with, it has a beautiful calming and clean atmosphere, the waiters are the funniest and kindest you will ever meet, and the udon is incredible! I want to highlight the chawamushi in particular which was amazingly done! Sashimi was great, not the best in LA, but still excellent compared to most places!
We had the mochis for dessert, which has the PERFECT texture! They don’t make their mochi, but it’s still worth mentioning. The meal was reasonably priced.
Prepare to have a memorable and an incredible experience on your trip to Aizen!

Great noods, service, and sake! Three of us came by on Saturday night without needing a reservation. Our waiter was kind and attentive, explaining the menu and offering his services as a sake sommelier.

One friend ordered the $45 Dine LA dinner course, which came with a set of 3 appetizers, a sashimi set of 3 fish (2 slices each), and a signature udon. It was also supposed to come with a dessert, which they forgot to give us (and we forgot to ask). She chose the tan tan udon, which had a thick, heavy, spicy broth. I didn’t love it, and it took her a long time to work through it. The appetizers and sashimi were all delicious.

My other friend ordered the $31 uni ankake udon, which came with a semi-gelatinous broth. And I ordered the $12 kitsune udon, which was clean and simple. I prefer their broth to Marugame’s.

I also ordered “The Legendary Sake Sampler”, $22, of which the KID junmai ginjo was my favorite, and the sake sommelier’s too.

Overall, this is a creative udon spot with attentive service and a trendy venue.

What an experience! When my boyfriend and I walked in the staff immediately greeted us, so 5/5 for friendly and helpful service. The waiters were very attentive and the owner was very passionate about sake and helped us choose one that paired perfectly with our dinner.
Since it was our first time we decided to try the tasting menu they had. (Note this is a limited time thing)  the udons are amazing to say the least… I highly recommend you try this place out for yourself! You won’t be disappointed!

Thank you to the staff for treating us to a wonderful dinner! 🍲🍥

Will go again / price = $15-25 / service = above average / cleanliness = above average

GRAND OPENING = I heard about this place Aizen from a coworker who mentioned a new udon spot that is comparable to Marugame. As I very much enjoyed the sea urchin uni cream udon there, I had to check out Aizen. Perfect timing in that I came during the Dine LA restaurant week so the dinner = $45. This included a 3 set appetizer + 3 set assorted sashimi + choice of udon + dessert. All but the udon is chef's choice. What a great deal!

My udon of choice was the Pescatore Udon which although is a "today's special" seems to be a standard menu item now. In addition, while I waited for my friend, I ordered the Uji Green Tea Plum Wine which was light, sophisticated, and delicious. The 3 appetizers were roast beef with truffle soy, mini chawannuchi, and eggplant in soy. Light but flavor explosion of Japanese goodness...the sashimi set was another delicious set of toro tuna, salmon, and yellow tail. Good size and very fresh in taste as it melts in your mouth like butter. The Pescatore Udon definitely has the Italian vibe it gives off and while it drains down your throat like a delicious liquid like soup, at the same time, it is slightly thick like a tomato cream sauce as it costs all the seafood and udon noodles so you can slurp like no other.

They recently had a grand opening and based on my experience, this will be a hotspot for something different than a traditional Japanese udon restaurant. The interior is casual but elegant with decor. Secret parking is available but I will not share so it does not become overused. It is a secret after all!

Thanks to Aizen for a great experience and Dine LA restaurant week!

Came here while we were waiting on Marugame Monzo, but this is probably going to be our top choice from now on.

Excellent service - the waiter gave us a detailed rundown of the menu (their selection of udons, appetizers, and sakes are amazing). Later in the meal they discovered that we were there for a birthday, and we got some excellent sashimi on the house. Service kind, attentive, and made us feel at home throughout.

Food - the udon is as good as anything I've had in LA (including Marugame!) They have a range of more standard offerings, and the broth is excellent, but the highlight for us was definitely the Uni Cream Udon - rich without being overpowering, and perfectly balanced. The appetizer selection is excellent, and the fish quality is some of the best in LA. Would also return here just for the sushi/sashimi - when we enter the waiter claimed that they had some of the best fish in LA, and they certainly lived up to this bold statement!

name: Mitsuru Sushi & Grill
address: 316 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Nice little hole in the wall with affordable food! I discovered this place back in undergrad when they had (and still do) have very affordable lunch specials. Will definitely be back.

At the time of our visit, I believe there was only 1 server, but later on (when we were leaving), we saw another staff member walk in.
know that the food will take time to be ready,  it seems like they prepare meals as they are ordered with few items done ahead of time. The wait is totally worth it, food is fantastic.

If you’ve visited Little Tokyo several times and have tried all the Instagram-worthy restaurants you may start to ask yourself, “where can I go to just feel comfortable?” Then you definitely want to try Mitsuru Sushi and Grill. This is a no-frills Japanese diner that serves one of the local favorites- “The Gacha.” It’s something every local loves. You can’t really call yourself a connoisseur of Little Tokyo food until you’ve had this unique breakfast/brunch item. What is the “Gacha” you ask? Basically it’s an omelette filled with your choice of protein (sausage, spam, etc.) and served with either hash browns or rice (the better choice). The salty omelette is perfectly paired with the rice and envelops your tastebuds and hugs your soul with pure goodness! The staff there are what you’d expect from a friendly neighborhood diner- great people who want to feed you a great meal.

A Symphony of Flavors at Mitsuru Sushi and Grill

After an extended hiatus from indulging in the art of sushi, my return to the experience at Mitsuru Sushi and Grill was nothing short of extraordinary. This hidden gem, which I stumbled upon through a friend’s recommendation, proved to be a culinary revelation.

As a party of three, we embarked on a gastronomic journey, each selecting different dishes to sample the breadth of the menu. The ‘Special B’ sushi platter at Mitsuru was a masterful display of freshness and finesse, each slice of sashimi whispering tales of the sea with its impeccable texture and taste. The ‘Rainbow Roll,’ true to its name, was a vibrant mosaic of flavors that melded in harmony, captivating our palates with every bite.

The Ramen was an authentic rendition of this classic dish, with a broth that was rich and robust, cradling tender slices of pork that melted in our mouths, while the marinated eggs added a level of umami that was simply transcendent. The Gyozas were the perfect accompaniment, their crisp exteriors giving way to succulent fillings that were a testament to the chef’s prowess at Mitsuru.

It’s not just the food that makes Mitsuru Sushi and Grill special. It’s the feeling of discovery, the joy of sharing exceptional food with good company, and the promise of returning to what now feels like a culinary haven.

In conclusion, Mitsuru Sushi and Grill is a celebration of Japanese cuisine, a place where each dish is crafted with passion and precision. For anyone seeking an authentic sushi experience, Mitsuru deserves not just a visit, but an encore.

I don't know who wrote good reviews. This restaurant smells bad as soon as you enter the entrance. I didn't express myself because I followed my group. It's a bad smell that I can't get used to. I decided to leave a review on the odor that lowers my appetite. I've been to many old restaurants, but I've never seen such a smelly and dirty place (dust accumulated in the corner of the carpet, an unorganized display).
Even the server sprayed a strong scent of perfume.

name: Tenno Sushi
address: 207 S Central Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Great spot for sushi in Little Tokyo. We came for the sushi and sashimi lunch combos and were surprised by how good the portion size was. The sushi and sashimi were very fresh.

We added the miso pork belly and mixed tempura to our order as well. The miso pork belly came with a super delicious and garlicky aioli that we were obsessed with.

We found out they serve oysters here as well.

We were near little Tokyo so must stop in for sushi.  Found this place off the Metro A line and no wait!  Quite a bit of selections for sushi and other stir fried dishes.  We got the spider roll, rainbow roll and the spicy seafood miso soup.  Everything was good and the soup has plenty of seafood in it.  Quite tasty.

A solid sushi spot in little Tokyo of LA. This spot is surrounded by lots of stores and Japanese restaurants/shops.

I ordered a miso soup, scallop uni and the Jessica alba roll. The scallop uni was phenomenal and a great mix, tasted very fresh and balanced.

The Jessica Alba roll was also very good and one of my favorite rolls without rice. The miso soup was also a great starter. The salmon skin salad was also very great and one of my favorite versions of this salad. Lots of salmon skin pieces and the dressing was just right.

I’d definitely come back here again to try their other menu items.  Parking is limited to street so Uber if you can.

Wonderful. Slight misunderstanding with Saki size but it was handled well and satisfactory. Food was soooo delicious and filling. Hella dark from the tinted windows but inside as you can see it's a great mood and service. Regulars were behind us and spoke highly so we felt even more comfortable

Me and my hubby ordered too many like more than 5 dishes. Everything was surprisingly tasty and has a good balance each of them. Fresh, perfect taste(not too sweet), generous portion, and friendly even though they were busy! Worthy to eat out!

name: Ramen Yamadaya
address: 137 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: Portion sizes for the bao buns are a bit small, the fried crab one was $9 but wasn’t satisfying and the inside just tasted like mush. The sauce overpowered everything, but didn’t taste bad overall. Everything else was fine.

Feeling under the cold weather, but love to warm my appetite by ordering the Chicken Wanton Ramen. Best choice so far, if you want a fusion ramen with bite size chicken wantons and savory noodles with mixed beansprouts and green onions, be their guest! Also the Chicken Katsu Buns are packed with the immense flavor of crispy chicken glazed in sauce and fresh veggies!

Food is good. Service was respectful nothing stood out about it. I went there for the Katsu Buns and they were out. The place looks a little run down and the bathrooms were the ones that need big help. The walls were disgusting. Everyone said thank you and goodbye when we left.

I ordered Yamadaya Ramen. My first impression when they served me, it didn’t look appetizing and also the ramen they use is very thin and smooth. After eating the ramen, I kind of like the broth. Somehow it’s kind of addictive to me. Unfortunately in my opinion, all ingredients in one bowl are well-balanced. Somehow the sliced pork is too thick. The only thing I can say is, I love the broth. I don’t recommend the Bento set. Far from what I expected

I came here awhile back with my boyfriend and the food was pretty good! I was a little nervous about the food being good because the menu seemed to be a bit outdated, but everything turned out great. The staff was friendly and we didn’t wait too long to get our food. I liked the gyozas the best and the ramen broth was good, definitely not as fatty as other ramens that I’ve had but it was still tasty.

name: bb.q Chicken LA Little Tokyo
address: 442 E 2nd St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: I recently dined at this restaurant after being intrigued by its portrayal in a Korean drama, and I was amazed by the welcoming ambiance and surroundings. The chicken dishes, especially the chicken golden original half and wings soy garlic, were incredibly appetizing and offered a distinctive taste. The service was exceptional, with Marsia leading the way and providing superb suggestions. The food arrived promptly, and the staff were friendly and professional. I wholeheartedly recommend this restaurant for an unforgettable dining experience that will leave you craving for more.

BB. Q chicken is a decent place to come in for a quick bite to eat. Price for the amount of food is good and the food tastet good. The food is a little heavy with mayobased sauces and cheese. I got a bowl of chicken, mayo cheese which was enough to still take to go and finish later.

If you come during happy hour make sure to clearly state and ask the staff what it is you ordered. I got my meal from the happy hour menu when ordering and was charged regular price for my meal which added a couple more buck for the same item. When I told staff they mentioned ohh you didn't stated what you ordered was from the happy hour menu, I payed the difference.

Food is pretty good, no say in that. It is also slightly expensive.

I suggest the owner edit their operating hours, we were on a schedule and went here thinking they open at noon (that's what google says). but they open at 12.30.

If you plan to go here be prepared to wait for your food, they take some time (I'm not complaining, the food tastes great).

Terrible service here, we only ordered a small chicken and rice, it took 45 minutes to come out. We saw our food passed from the kitchen to the counter for it to be served and it was left ignored and turning cold in front of our eyes while the cashier guy restocked and cleaned instead of serving. By the time we got our food it was no longer hot even though we saw it finished, no one was there to take it from the kitchen and serve it. Had to stand up and ask for the chopsticks, water, to order, etc and were not approached by anyone except the give the menu. customers had to stand up to pay for the bill upfront by approaching the cashier (which isn’t a problem if that’s how the restaurant operates, but they had brought the bill to other tables and then ignored others for an extended period of time). I’ve also been to other bbq chicken branches where the service is great. The lady who is supposed to be the server was on her phone for most of the time we were there, and took a 25 minute phone call while customers were trying to wave her down and get her attention. Wouldn’t eat at this bbq chicken branch for that reason. Would give a 1 star but the food tasted fine so that’s for the kitchen.

If you like fried chicken you need to go here.  Their chicken is so damn crispy and flavorful we even ate it refrigerated and still cold the next day and it was still crispy and flavorful!  This place does it right. Unfortunately not all BB.Q chicken places are the same. Others were a miss compared to this location. I gotta say I absolutely hate LA, but this is one of the few placesi need to visit when in town. Cut out the guesswork, get the original crispy. Then you can try some other flavors.  No need to waste your time on sides just stick to the chicken.

name: Zencu Sushi & Grill
address: 319 E 2nd St #206, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
A new family tradition is born. One week visit to see the family had dinner here twice. It's rare when the whole family is satisfied at the same time. Just my experience, they gave bigger portions just before closing time. If you are in LA for a visit or residence give them a try. You'll love it. Can't wait until my next trip.
Just found out the tip was charged with the bill. I guess they got me twice. I will never go back to this place again. Just remember her face counting the cash as we walked out. Totally uncool. Thanks, Lorenzo for dropping the knowledge.

Went here today around 5PM and it was only a little bit of people. We ordered 3 rolls and it came out a total around 70 dollars. (The hot tea also costed money) Prices were pretty absurd and the food wasn’t that good either.

Mediocre Japanese food, no parking validation, and FORCED tips.

Are tips obligatory even if the food was okay-ish? Of course not. Tips are an optional add-on to the dining expenses. But not here. (Look pictures) When you are about to pay, you already have included 20% tip on your purchase. We just wanted to give a 10% tip because the food was mediocre and overpriced... The interesting thing is that you CANNOT change or remove the tip, we asked, and they said because they were 5 of us. It is funny that it says "tip suggestion: 15%, 20%, etc." when you can not even change or remove the tip rate! Now we understand why tipping culture is getting out of our hands...

Now the food... Is "meh", you won't be having the "mmm's" when eating here. Tired chicken yakisoba, and the taste is ordinary, chewy chicken, not special at all. Ordered California rolls and it was regular sushi with no dressing. Soft drinks are $3.5 each. Water tastes like high school water fountain. Overall, the food is not the main reason you will be here...

The atmosphere is great! This is the part that it stands out from other restaurants. The reason is that it has a nice entrance, with stairs and banners everywhere. The dining building itself is comfortable, and there is plenty of lighting.

No parking validation. It would be nice considering since it is $4 per 15min, or $16 max.

Overall, our recommendation is that you should give it a try, but we want to let you know what to expect: okay-ish Japanese food, forced 20% tip, and overpriced food.

Why overpriced and not expensive?

Expensive: You get a lot of food, that tastes good, but it will cost you... Well worth it!

Overpriced: not a lot of food, food taste is forgettable. Still hurts your wallet. You will probably leave sad or betrayed... Or both.

Amazing sushi here. The fish is really fresh. The rolls are pretty big portions. Everything tastes amazing and goes well. Pretty much the best sushi I've ever had except some of the rolls are pretty spicy. We ordered a little too much and the price came out a little high, But you only need to order like one or two rolls per person honestly. We got literally like seven rolls and everything came out amazing. Not a single miss. The vibe and ambiance is lively and The service is phenomenal. All the waiters are very kind and The food came out really really fast like really really fast. Everything about the this place is Wonderful! Coming back here another time.
Fresh seafood and excellent service. The soft shell crab is amazing! Tako was fresh and soft, perfect 👌🏻

name: Manuela
address: 907 E 3rd St, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews:
Located in the Arts District of DTLA, Manuela was such a vibe. From the ambiance to the excellent service to the delicious food, I really enjoyed it all. My sister felt the food was better in theory than actually execution but she's also a chef who works for a Michelin star chef, so her standards are a wee bit higher than ours, the layman. LOL

I loved how thorough the menu was in listing all the ingredients of each dish! I really appreciate menus like that. Both indoor and outdoor seating were beautiful. Everything was solid.

My husband loves cornbread, so I ordered one to-go for him. The server told us that they were made-to-order, so she would fire it up a little before we were ready to leave. My husband was so excited when I gave it to him after I got home. WHAT AN UTTER DISAPPOINTMENT! It was the *driest*, most flavorless cornbread we had ever had in our lives. It wasn't sweet at all but maybe that was because they included what tasted like a maple butter on the side.

I told one of my besties and he said that he had had it before and that it was really good. So he felt it was possible that it was some kind of off-day they were having with the cornbread.

That was the reason for one-star drop for me. Otherwise, everything else was excellent.

This place for me is 10/10. It is such beautiful place, the food is more than delicious I highly recommend to get the full experience about appetizers, mains and desserts. There is not anything wrong at this place. Our server Medina made us feel so special. Soooo if anyone wants such special and gastronomic experience in LA definitely you all should go to Manuela. Can’t wait to go back

This is my second visit. I'm still impressed with the food—I love the oysters. They're fresh, and the topping enhances them beautifully. If you are a mushroom lover, don't miss out on the hen of the wood mushrooms. I love how they combine with the cornbread (which is similar to cornbread). It adds more flavor and sweetness together.

And always, shout out to the steak—it's so perfect you can't criticize it.

I had brunch here with a group of 6 over the weekend.

Positives:

Overall, experience was good. Quality of the food was good with decent portion sizes. The ambiance was what you'd expect from a restaurant in the Arts District of LA: converted industrial space to a trendy indoor/outdoor restaurant. Despite the heat, there was great sun cover and we were very comfortable outside. The place looks nice, has cool stuff nearby (art museum and chicken coop/garden), and feels secluded from the rest of downtown LA.

The food was tasty. Our table ordered a burger, 3 eggs benedicts, beignets, and french toast. The first three were great, and I was surprised to see the benedict served on bread pudding with a slightly spicy ham. The french bread was probably the only thing that pulled the food rating down. This thing was THICC, and except for a bit in the middle, was a little too dry - not what you expect from french toast, in my opinion. It just felt like I was eating a dense loaf of bread with a bit of fruit and whipped cream on top, and really could have used something more to make it more moist.

Could have been better:

Service was solid, but the only thing that rubbed me the wrong way was the restaurant gratuity fees, which come automatically applied (but can be removed at request).

This 2% fee is for a living wage or whatever, which I just don't feel like is my responsibility - if you want to provide this, why don't you pay the servers more? I realize there are complexities to pricing and running restaurants I'm not aware of, so this may be a much larger problem.

There's also an automatic 20% gratuity added for groups of 6 or more. We typically tip this much already, but just having that automatically selected is frustrating because it no longer feels like a choice to tip 20%, but instead is an obligation.

What a gorgeous place to have lunch/brunch. Vibe's chill and food was amazing!

Food/Drinks: Food was delicious. Our server recommended the cream biscuits to start, and her suggestion was on point. Best flaky bread I've ever had! I personally ended up having their venison burger, and it has earned being one of their most popular dish for a reason. It was recommended medium rare and it was super juicy. However, the best dish we had was the shared roasted cauliflower dish. It was seasoned amazingly well and I highly would recommend this as your filler!

Service/Ambiance: Top notch. Server was really knowledgeable on immediately started recommending dishes. Throughout our entire meal, other staff members would come by and clear our dishes as we finish them and provided new utensils. Huge plus. And obviously cannot disregard the views/ambiance! Outdoorsy feel and not chilly since they had heaters on.

Rating: 10/10
Recommendations: Roasted cauliflower, cream biscuits!

name: Sushi Kaneyoshi
address: 250 1st St B1, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: "Sushi Kaneyoshi in LA is legit! The omakase is fire 🔥—fresh fish and flavors that pop. The chefs are chill and know their stuff. It's pricey but worth every penny for the experience. Definitely a must-try for sushi lovers!"

So far, this is my other favorite besides Sushi Takeda. It came with so many dishes, and every individual one was detailed and well-made. They only have one session per day, and the setting is very authentic Japanese style. This is the omakase place that I’ll keep coming back to.
Top quality seafood, amazing craftsmanship, and abundant varieties! My favorites were the oyster and monkfish liver!

Good, but honestly not worth the hassle of getting a reservation when you will find an equally satisfactory (or better) experience at 715 Sushi, Ginza, or Morihiro. There was nothing that especially wowed me, though my favorite dishes of the night were the ankimo (monkfish liver) and mackerel handroll.

Unlike the other omakase restaurants I mentioned, Sushi Kaneyoshi did not offer dessert nor the option of adding extra courses at the end of this meal. I was quite disappointed with receiving just tamago at the end and would have ordered extra courses.

The restaurant seats 11 people, which ends up feeling like a less intimate experience than other places that seat far fewer. To be honest, my experience was ruined sitting next to 3 raucous regulars who were friendly with the chef and enjoyed making their conversations and antics known to the entire room.

Deliberately hard to find from the outside, refined Japanese craftsmanship inside, with just enough Los Angeles flair.

Food is superb, and if you can snag a reservation to one of the Kaneyoshi x Inaba collaboration nights, it's even better, if that's believable. The latter are not cheap (paying two chefs, each with their own Michelin star, never is), but it's so good.

name: Eigikutei
address: 314 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
The Vegan Taste menu didn't disappoint. It was such a parade of color, delicate and well balance flavors. Except for the dessert, the coconut flavor overpowered the flavor of the ice cream.
Wonderful, friendly, attentive and staff, they made our time in Eigikutei a memorable one.
Clean restroom
PARKING TIP $3 flat fee after 5pm Aiso parking garage 101 Judge John Aiso St

We chose this restaurant to celebrate our 35th wedding anniversary and had the 7 course Plant Based Kaiseki Tasting Menu.  It was so delicious.
Every item that came out was so beautifully and artfully presented.  It was really like eating artworks.  Each item is also healthy and simple but the taste is so 'balanced.'  It is hard to describe the deliciousness but my palate knows it.
Also, it seems that each item is small in portion(except the hot pot) but at the end of our meals we were both very full and satisfied.

The main entree is a big portion of Japanese hot pot with all different kinds of mushrooms , 2 different kinds of tofu, and different kinds of Asian vegetables.  A plate of udon was added at the end to the hot pot.  The broth of the hot pot was a delicious sesame miso and soy milk broth.  So yum!

The service was excellent.  Waitress and manager helped us with the hot pot and cleared dirty dishes quickly.  Even the owner came and helped us.  She was so sweet and when we told her about the tough stem of one of the vegetables that she wanted to correct this problem for future customers and makes sure that it will be corrected.  It shows that this restaurant cares about the quality of their products.

The ambience was calm and serene although the outside of this restaurant is busy LA downtown streets.   We  don't hear what is going on outside once inside the restaurant but a nice, serene, and calming music.

At the end of the meals we were treated with a special desserts on the house for our anniversary that includes red bean cakes, mochi cakes, and fresh fruits.  This is on top of the black sesame and cacao plant based ice creams that were included in the meal.

I was so happy that I picked this restaurant for our celebration.  We will be back with our friends.

We came on a Sunday night and parked at Aiso Parking garage which is located 1/2 a block diagonally from the restaurant.  It turned out the parking was free after 5 pm.  Nice!

If you want true, authentic Japanese food with the best quality and the dedication of skill in the food, then this restaurant is the perfect place to explore for you. This family owned restaurant, they care so much about the food and setvice. They are perfectionist on how to bring the best ans plate it on the dishes. they are constantly evolving. I have been eating lots of Japanese food in my life. This is one of the most authentic Japanese food I ever had. Deliciousness and dining experiences are  beyond my imagination. I highly recommended it

Been here twice it’s located in the heart of little Tokyo on 1st street. The food and service is incredible! The restaurant is gorgeous, simple minimalist Japanese.

Both times we’ve ordered the Yosenabe Kaiseki course. It’s really delicious and there’s many courses. Everything is presented beautifully. Our meal  started off with 3 appetizers, sashimi, chawanmushi (so silky), soup and the basket full of seafood. It also came with a side of udon & porridge. Followed by dessert and tea. Everything so good! And so much food!

We’ve also been to their bar on a couple of occasions  & they have an extensive sake list. They even have sparkling sake! My new favorite. They also have a great bar food menu. Highly recommend this gem.

The owner Tomoko is lovely

My experience, from three visits total were all positive.  I think the cost performance is good considering how expensive sushi omakase can be lately.  They have three price options for each menu.  I tried all options for sushi omakase.  My favorite pick is the middle one.

name: Sushi & Teri
address: 116 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
I’m still traumatized 😵‍💫from the time I came here to order like maybe 2 plates of sushi and a miso soup for me and homie— cuz we were jus vibin in Lil Tokyo and felt a bit peckish for some grub. 🌞all was wonderful until when we watched three other tables that had their orders taken after ours….get served their dishes and finish.

While me and homie uhhh waited 40 minutes(a very generous rounded down estimation 😵‍💫because our server passed by and said almost there every 10 minutes after that) . It’s a stressful job during lunch hours I’m sure but they were able to serve a large table(6-7 ppl?), a party of 1, and another table of 3— while me and bestie their sat kinda hungry and uhh kinda trynna not lose our minds as other tables stared at us sitting like the sims for 40 minutes straight yapping and trynna forget that we were starving when we had other places and things we wanted to go see as well 😭😔 that day we deliberated tipping for the first time in our lives.

The server wasn’t unkind…I think she was doing her best.

but it felt like there was an understaffed problem here— yet on the other hand I felt like I couldn’t forgive gurlie for making us sit and wait and then remind her that all we ordered was plates of 8 pieces sushi and a bowl of soup. She was doing her best but still— I saw the ppl constantly making orders over there at the kitchen too…jus dunno what was goin on that day with them man…
🤨um Sushi & Teri— please😭do better. Maybe hire enough staff??? IDK 😭 EXPLAIN How and why you had one person-server who served everyone but they also just didn’t bother serving us. For like. The hour we were there. (Actually don’t explain 😵‍💫just don’t do this to ur customers again yall)

Atmosphere was okay…it’s a small space: but that being said I think the goal would be to let ppl get their meals also they can leave and you can have more customers come in…

Anyways food was okay. I didn’t expect anything exciting or anything for a 15?16? Dollar per sushi plate and like 2-3$ miso soup. It was the Alaska and Baja rolls— so like fish- rice-seaweed- and avocado and the gist— you kinda can’t go wrong with that.
Food is food. And it was edible and tasted as expected 👍 did waiting to eat for an hour ruin the taste? Yes. But did I still tip? Yeah. I did 😭😭because idk MANNERS MATTER besties.

Solid Japanese food restaurant. The portions are a bit smaller than surrounding restaurants but it is cheaper. I like the Ramen here because they bring it to you piping hot which is what I like. Japanese noodle places tend to serve Ramen lukewarm which is not my style. The cucumber salad is great and the service is top notch! Will come back for sure!

Decent Sushi experience in Little Tokyo. The food and service were both average. The sushi selection was okay, but not exceptional. The service was friendly but not particularly attentive.
As for the price level, I was pleasantly
surprised. The prices were reasonable and reflected the average dining experience. If you find yourself in Little Tokyo and get hungry, this restaurant is an option to get a satisfying meal. While it may not be an exceptional experience, it serves its purpose.

My favorite Japanese Sushi Restaurant in LA!😍
Very tasty and affordable, the best atmosphere is to eat outside (wooden tables)✨
Superfriendly stuff!

No need to wait on staff since there’s a tablet to order which was super helpful! Food was DELICIOUS. I got the Washington roll which has salmon. And yummm the salmon legit melts in ur mouth! Very good quality stuff

name: Tamon Sushi
address: Miyako Hotel 2F, 328 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: We came here for lunch on a Monday (Oct 9, 2023) as most of the highly-rated sushi spots are closed on Mondays in Little Tokyo. The dining room was empty except for one other table. This place is located inside a hotel on the second floor. The sushi is definitely fresh but the preparation style wasn’t a fit for us. The salmon sashimi and nigiri (and a few other types of fish) are presented with the chewy skin still on which leaves an undesirable texture. While it does look artsy (and allows the restaurant to serve fish parts that most others would trim away), it wasn’t palette friendly for us. We also tried the wagyu sushi which the server verified for us was Japanese A5 wagyu but it didn’t hit the mark. I’m not sure what was going on as it did not have the baseline umami that A5 has and tasted like American wagyu. Miso soup came with my entree and the soup was brought out after my entree was out for a bit. The staff was kind but seemed like a new crew. $100+ for a subpar LA sushi experience. There are much better places in LA.

Tamon Sushi is an underrated gem, located on the second floor of the Miyako Hotel. Japanese hospitality with Japanese-speaking servers, serving authentic Washoku.

I’ve stayed loyal to Tamon throughout the years, including when they downsized their menu to only sushi, and am glad that they are back in full force now.

Definitely try their Fatty Fish nigiri set ($20), which features select chu-toro, yellowtail, and salmon at 2 pieces each, or their Senior Bento ($25) which features grilled fish, simmered veggies, mixed tempura, rice and miso soup.

LOVE their happy hour, which features reduced sake, shochu, and beer options to pair with their fabulous food offerings. Happy hour runs from 5:30-7:30pm, and simply rocks. Closed Sundays and Wednesdays.

Excellent views over Historical 1st Street, calm ambiance with plenty of choices to suit any taste. This place consistently earns their 5 stars.
Quiet unassuming restaurant on the second floor of the hotel.  I was the only customer at 6:30 on a Monday evening.  Staff lovely. Chirashi heavenly and $50 well spent.

We found this gem of a restaurant hidden on the second floor of the Miyako hotel. It's one of the best kept secrets in LA! Delicious and authentic Japanese food. Fresh and tasty seafood! Try the Chirashi!

TAMON is such a cozy Japanese restaurant in Downtown, Los Angeles!
Staffs were very friendly and courteous.

I had the Wonton Shio(Salt) Ramen, with the Garlic Butter Pork Gyoza(dumpling).  Super authentic quality and great price.
I will definitely go back there to try other Ramen (Garlic Tonkotsu Ramen) next time!

I highly recommend tthis restaurant. : )

name: Korean Kitchen Hibachi BBQ.
address: 135 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: We were all satisfied with our food. Waiter was nice to us, my dad was pleased and he's not easily pleased. We didn't know that for 5 people or more they automatically deduct a tip, (we had 6 people ) so when we left cash at the table they stopped is outside and told us we OVER TIPPED witch was really nice of them to be honest with us. Its a small place but at the  VERY BACK there's two tables with setting for 6 people each.
Quality of food was amazing. If you're dining in, it is a bit cramped which is why we did take out.  Atmosphere is generally very welcoming!

My family and I would go here all the time and Gina, the owner was ALWAYS so kind we would have good laughs with her. 🥰 Tonight we came in and found out that Gina retired and sold the place to someone who had worked with her before. I think she left her place in good hands. The food was still just as good as I remembered it to be and the service was awesome. The new owner, Andrew was always checking up to make sure everything was okay.

We ordered the Tofu BBQ (medium spicy) and vegetarian bibimbap. DELICIOUS and flavorful!

We will miss you here Gina! ❤️

GREAT!!! A bit expensive, however the food is over-the-top, 5 star food!!! No single complaint! The waiters are also very nice and helpful. It's not your average fake Asian restaurant, so I totally reccomend going when having the chance!!!

The sushi was pretty good, as well as the edamame! We sat there for a bit after eating to get some rest and we felt the services looking at us, making us feel as if we needed to leave soon. Other than that, it was good

name: Little Tokyo Market Place
address: 333 S Alameda St #100, Los Angeles, CA 90013, USA
reviews: This little market is adjacent to a mall that has a Daiso store. We had planned on eating at the sushi restaurant on the 3rd floor of the mall, but it was closed that day, so we wandered into the market place. They have everything, and reasonable prices. They also have a fresh sushi bar. The sushi was prepackaged when we arrived, so I was skeptical that it would be any good, but after we made our purchase and found a table outside to eat at, we discovered that the sushi was delicious and the miso soup was the best I've had. I would definitely shop there again and buy sushi for lunch.
Incredible supermarket that has not only Korean/asian products but also imported and local goods. The variety is amazing and was completely unexpected

A nice little Japanese community area with some stores and restaurants. It can get crowded during afternoon time but it’s not a big deal and still can walk around. My favourite place will probably be a Japanese restaurant with sushi on little trains that you can pick it up yourself, very interesting!
So many authentic and interesting stores! Very similar to real Japanese markets. Take ur time to explore and wander! You never know what hidden gems there are if u don’t look down the side paths

Big market with a variety of foods. Their produce section was huge and they have live crabs and lobsters! They had little sample areas all throughout and the people in the beauty area were so sweet and helpful. Honestly, loved their customer service and of you're there, check out their Besitos soda, it was really good.

name: Hachioji Craft & Vegan Ramen
address: 313 1st St, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: One of the best vegan ramen in Downtown. I had white creamy ramen with very good gluten-free noodles. Also gyozas and avocado-veggie sushi with leafy salad with tasty vegan dressing - everything this was good! Pretty nice vegan menu for a reasonable price! Nice service, thank you!

Great ramen, cool vibes. Of all the ramen spots we visited in Little Tokyo, this was the best. We saw lines out the doors at other places but this is seemingly a hidden gem. The shoyu broth was insanely good. The spicy ramen was bonkers. It verges on the edge of “too spicy” but spice-heads will love it. 10/10. Will visit again.

Traveling with my father who has never had ramen or gyoza in his life and I don't think I could have picked a better place in all of the world outside of Japan for him to try. This place is awesome, the service and the atmosphere is top notch and the food was delicious 😋 I was in heaven and the happy hour beer was a great deal. My Dad loved it he said it was so flavorful and said he's never had anything like it. It was awesome to share this experience and I would eat here again any day of the week. I am fat and happy and you should be too!

As I walked in, I was warmly greeted by a friendly Japanese lady quickly set me down. The place feels very authentic. I ended up ordering the Ramen with the duck and gyoza. The green tea from Dan was also delicious. The only thing I would say is that the place needs to be touched up and cleaned up more regularly. As well as the bathroom ghaving a fresh coat of paint. Other than that…I will definitely go there again as the food was great!
Two amazing options of vegan ramens. Loved both. Vegan white is creamy and not spicy.

name: Sushi Gala
address: 103 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: I haven't tried the sushi but the rolls were phenomenal. Probably the best rolls I tried in the area. Teppan yaki was on point and the service was spectacular!

I visited this place about a year and a half ago. It was decent. Didn't really get a chance to try the highlighted dishes.

The place is like half Sushi half American food. The vibe inside the building resembles that as well. Kind of unconventional but I guess they make it work.

I ordered the fried calamari and it was decent but nothing special.

Overall, this place was alright. It has both American food and sushi

The best place on the Plaza.  Their California Rolls and Spicy Tuna Rolls are delicious.  You order from a tablet (new) and your food will come out fast. Also tried the beef Bento box and it was delicious. Exceptional service.

Made the best choice dining at Sushi Gala/ Las Galas! Tonkotsu Ramen was crafted to perfection, its chashu pork slices flamed to a heavenly taste! Their recommendation was spot on with the Volcano, never had a baked roll before, topped with spicy crab, avocado, cucumber, but if you are use to eating spicy foods or not there are more portions to try out.

It was a great place to eat in a pinch in Little Tokyo. They had an array of option to choose from at a reasonable price. The place is not as much of a fancy atmosphere but it's clean. The service was amazing, the server sat us down promptly but we did have to flag their attention to get the check and to-go boxes.

We ordered fries (not pictured) but they aren't anything amazing and tasted a day old. The hand rolls were sensational and the yellowtail sushi roll was good too. These are amazing to order to beat the LA heat and cool down.

name: Korea BBQ House
address: 123 Astronaut Ellison S Onizuka St #302, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews:
Came here with the family, and I'd say that we had a great time. The food was brought in steaming a cloud on the hot plate, which was pretty cool to see. For the taste of the food, the meat was delicious, both sweet and savory at the same time. The sides were also good, like the rice, mashed potatoes, cucumber, and vegetables.

Apart from that, the server was nice, and the atmosphere of restaurant of itself was nice and cozy. Also a plus for bringing a chilled glass for my alcohol.

In LA, with this pricing, it’s probably the best food you can have in DT. The tri tips steak is fabulous. And it’s not less than 30? I can taste the sea food are frozen ones. But compared to the money I spent, there is nothing to complain. Highly Recommended if you are Asian who like to have something hot and quality food. Gyoza also very good.

Food was delicious and came quickly and with lots of delicious banchan. I ordered spicy short ribs and was left feeling full and happy. Just a warning that you'll smell like KBBQ since they cook everything right mext to the seating area. Overall very chill place.

Took my girl to this hidden gem. I’ve been to little Tokyo countless times but this restaurant has the BEST kbbq I’ve had and the best beef soup. Highly recommended. The food tasted like I was adopted into a Korean family and my mom just made me my Korean lunch

Decent spot with an OG feel. The lady that served us was a bit crotchety, but the rib + spicy pork combo was pretty solid.

The 12 oz beers are $5, large size (22 oz) are $10, small / large sake works the same way. Parking is validated up to 2 hours, at the rate of $2 per hour. I wish the service was a little lacking but all good otherwise!

name: Two Hands Corn Dogs - Little Tokyo
address: 118 Japanese Village Plaza Mall, Los Angeles, CA 90012, USA
reviews: I've always tried to like Korean corn dogs, but I'm too biased towards having more meat and less batter in my corn dogs. They do offer full sausages at a premium, but still feels kinda small. Still, if you're someone who likes this kind of food, you'll enjoy the selection that they offer here

Got the rice crunch cheese and meat corn dog with no sugar. It comes with ketchup and mustard on it. It was crunchy, cheesy and tasty. I thought it was good but I’d probably try one that has some different toppings on it next time.
My kids were excited to see a Two Hands Corn Dogs (while I had never heard of it). We ordered and have no regrets. Super good flavor combination. We're impressed and will definitely be returning!

Ordered the classic with half mozzarella cheese and half sausage topped with mustard and ketchup. This place serves it fresh. Would come again and try some of the other items. Price point is reasonable as well.
Great business model. Decent corn dogs, relatively fast service for how busy it stays. Good option for a casual/affordable bite

name: Sun Nong Dan
address: 3470 W 6th St #7, Los Angeles, CA 90020, USA
reviews: We got the Koh Galbi Jjim (large) and it was good for 5 people. The tteokbokki was really soft and the meat falls off the bone 😊

I normally don't leave reviews for this place I had to. Let's start with the food, absolutely amazing. I normally don't eat red meat but the beef and leek soup was BANGIN. The staff was amazing as well I was nervous going into the Korean restaurant but they made me feel right at home. the cook was so sweet and the to-go bowl she gave me made me feel like I was leaving my grandmother's house. So glad I tried this place. ILL BE BACK SOON !!
It’s just like being in Korea! Everything is so good. Would recommend any of the soups for a hearty meal! Bonus for it being open 24 hrs!

Love the soup Galbi Tang. Want to try their other menu too next time i will come back. 24hrs open. My 2nd time to come here i ordered suluh tang its good too you have to put some salt and pepper to make it more flavorful.

Most of the ox tail soup is a bit greasy to me, but the nice part is they give green onions, salt, and pepper for you to adjust the taste by yourself. The main problem is the service, one of the worker with glasses and cap are so rude, and the his attitude is like you own them money. In the beginning, my girlfriend ordered a spicy ox tail soup, due to most of the dishes are sold out or didn’t serve that day, she has less options to choose. After 2 minutes, we found out the soup contains beef intestines, which my girlfriend couldn’t eat, so I ask the server to change it to normal spicy beef soup. The sever replied to me: I already ordered it, and send it to the kitchen which feels like he’s not willing to make changes for me, and want us to eat the food that we don’t like. At the time, I was like it just nearly two minutes after the order, what are being that mad for? After that he’s shouting toward his colleagues (seems fighting) that all the customers in restaurant got influenced. In short, the food are nice and delicious but the workers attitude have to make some adjustments. I feel like I’m having dinner in a jail, and the warrant tells what you supposed to do. Whereas, I have to be fair, this store closed very late like till 3:00 AM, so it’s suitable for night owls.

name: Kobawoo House
address: 698 S Vermont Ave #109, Los Angeles, CA 90005, USA
reviews: Love the banchan here. We ordered medium bossam plate and the portion is enough to feed three people. Even though the meat is not as fall apart tender as Han****, the flavor here at Kobawaoo is wayyyyy better. We also ordered the the Jangban Guksoo, the acorn noodle was perfectly cooked, so aromatic, so good overall.

Kobawoo is the real deal for traditional Korean food. The pork bossam is super tender and flavorful, and the radish kimchi on the side is just perfect. The doenjang jjigae has such a rich, deep flavor – honestly, it’s better than a lot of places in Korea. The portions are generous, and the atmosphere is welcoming. If you're craving some authentic, casual Korean eats, this is the spot!

Old fashioned Korean food restaurant
It’s over 40years-olds! You can have original,old fashioned recipes here :) you can have unlimited small dishes.you can choose two types of the rice (which were white rice or  black rice)

The food was good! I didn’t find their seasoning too spicy nor too salty like at most Korean restaurants. The price was reasonable, too. We got their bossam (steamed pork) with soybean paste stew. While the pork wasn’t oily and was tasty, it lacked something. But, I honestly couldn’t put my finger on it. I would love to return and try their other items on the menu next time. Highly recommend!

Being a solo diner on a business trip has its disadvantages in this place, where the house specialties are for sharing with one other person or more. My loss.
But gripped with FOMO I did order their special seafood pancake which could have fed 4 people, but even though I ate 3/4 of it, with the aid of a soy sauce dip that came with the Banchan, by itself it did not set off fireworks.
The highlight was the Makkeoli, my favorite fermented rice drink, ordered the small version which sadly I could not finish.
Service was good but as usual solo diners everywhere are ignored after the food is served. But whenever I needed anything they came thru.
The place is busy on a weekday which is to their credit.
Groups of friends all around did seem to have a great time.

name: Pigya
address: 3400 W 8th St, Los Angeles, CA 90005, USA
reviews: You get a lot of food for the price. Our meat was tasty and tender. The servers round to ensure your food is cooked and cut to bite- sized portions. I would definitely come back here again. The environment is relaxed and they have cheap valet parking for 4 bucks. The only downside is that the grease can jump on you while your meat cooks.

Dining at Pigya in Los Angeles was a memorable experience that exceeded our expectations, thanks in large part to the exceptional service and culinary delights we encountered. From the moment we made reservations for our family of five, the awesome employees at Pigya ensured our visit was seamless and special.

Upon arrival, we were greeted by a friendly staff. The atmosphere was inviting, making us feel right at home.

Our server was the epitome of attentiveness, ensuring our every need was met with a smile. Their knowledge of the menu was impressive, guiding us through the selections with expert advice. This level of service was not only refreshing but significantly enhanced our dining experience.

We ordered pork gyu which was enough for our family. The banchans were delicious. Our server cooked the meats. Cooked to absolute perfection, every bite was a culinary revelation. The flavors were bold, yet perfectly balanced, showcasing a level of culinary craftsmanship that is hard to find.

Everything we ordered was delicious, leaving us thoroughly impressed and eager to return. Pigya in Los Angeles has not only mastered the art of cooking but also the ability to create a dining experience that feels both personal and extraordinary. This is a place where food and service come together in perfect harmony, making it a must-visit destination for anyone looking to indulge in some of the best cuisine LA has to offer.

We really enjoyed this place. Not ayce, but the tasting menu had plenty of meat. The meat quality was good. I'm from Portland so this was my first LA kbbq experience and I was very happy. The servers cook meat for you and they know how to cook. The atmosphere was loud but all Korean restaurants I went to in LA were loud.

Our new favorite KBBQ place! We recently dined Pigya, a kbbq spot we discovered through an Instagram post featuring Jungkook from BTS, and it exceeded all my expectations. We ordered pork belly, pork cheek, and the boneless beef short rib (꽃살), which was tender, flavorful, and delicious. The atmosphere was lively, perfect for both casual dining. Our server Jaehyuk was very attentive and friendly preparing the meat right at our table.

If you visit Pigya, I highly recommend trying the boneless beef short rib. We will be back!

We arrived at around 6 pm with a party of three, and the waiting time was approximately 5 minutes. We were seated at a nice table on the balcony. The barbecued pork dish was incredibly tender and delicious, and we were particularly impressed with the excellent service provided by our waitress. Overall, we had a delightful dining experience there.

name: Woo Hyang Woo
address: 3429 W 6th St, Los Angeles, CA 90020, USA
reviews: Woo Hyang Woo is a gem in the heart of Koreatown! Even on a busy Saturday night, we got seated immediately. We went for the brisket special and char pork ribs. The brisket was decent, but the ribs stole the show—served on a sizzling plate and packed with incredible flavor. I could seriously eat this every day! Plus, you get unlimited soybean soup, all for just $24. Amazing deal! The service was top-notch too. Highly recommend!

We had a group of 7 come here on a Tuesday night and were able to get seated immediately. The ambiance is pretty typical for a KBBQ place. They are known for their tomahawk here, but we opted for a group dining option. The meats were seasoned well and the banchan were pretty simple. You have the option of having it pre-cooked and just brought to your table or have it cooked in front of you. Overall, a pretty decent deal for what you get. Service could have been a little bit more attentive since at times we felt a little forgotten even though it wasn't too busy, but a pretty decent place for KBBQ.

Very nice place. Dark ambience. I liked the food, and while the servers were friendly, they helped us with changing out the grill, and made good suggestions. But on a technical matter, the staff seemed to have trouble transferring things off the wax paper onto the grill. Some pieces occasionally fell off onto the table.
But otherwise, food was really good.
Absolutely fire. Everyone who works here is sick. All the other restaurants around had ridiculous waits but we got right in and were super happy with everything. Def recommend.

We came around 6pm when it was raining on a weekend. Im not sure if this is their usual option, but we were able to request all the meats be cooked by them at the kitchen. It came out piping out and delicious :) also got lots of refills on the side dishes. Posted photo is the smallest size of the tomahawk state, OH BOY it took a while for it to come out but dang it was delicious since it comes to around medium-rare (medium if u leave it on the iron plate). Highly recommend if you go with a group :3!

name: Dan Sung Sa
address: 3317 W 6th St, Los Angeles, CA 90020, USA
reviews:
The food was great, the atmosphere was amazing.
The service was also great. Will definitely go there again.

The food prices and portions were the best. Not expensive at all while having a really good quality dishes.

Love this place

Second time here and I’m already looking forward to my next visit.
Amazing food sorted by price, there’s something for everyone. Great service as well, would highly recommend.

My husband and I came here on our first night visiting LA and waited outside for more than an hour…but it was totally worth it. One of the perfect portraits of an ideal K town restaurant experience - this area is sprawling so it can take a while to mine the gems, but once you do the places that come out on top are keepers. First thing’s first the ambiance is unforgettable. Rowdy but not overwhelming, enough space to comfortably fit people but you’re at a good distance to bump shoulders if you want. While I’ve lived in NYC and been to several fun pochas/izakayas, this one felt like it was on a bigger scale yet dare I say homier level of authenticity.

Skewers were what I wish all izakaya skewers would taste like. Stir fried spicy squid were familiarly saucy and satisfying, especially for late night. Steamed pork belly was filling and well balanced with the wraps. Yogurt soju came in a fun kettle-like vessel. Just LOVE the vibes.

This is such a fun place to drink and eat small bites with friends. Recommend a group of a least 4 for the full experience and making a reservation ahead of time or expect to wait a long time. Feels super authentic and like something you’d find in Seoul.

I think they have larger dishes but mostly it’s grilled skewers or other proteins. The short rib and intestines (yes intestines) were my fave. Order as you see fit along with rounds of soju and beer. All in all a great time.

The only good thing about this place is the decor.
1. You absolutely need to buy an overpriced alcoholic drink to order any of their grilled items.
2. The food is bland/ tasteless - some items not even cooked through.
3. The service is very minimal.
4. They give you a handwritten receipt in Korean so you have no idea of the receipt details.

Overall, did not like it. Giving 2 stars cuz the decor was cool.

name: Borit Gogae
address: 3464 W 8th St, Los Angeles, CA 90005, USA
reviews: This was my first time trying food prepared this way, and it's very different from other Korean restaurants. On my initial visit, I found the staff friendly and the ambiance pleasant. The food was enjoyable, especially the combination of veggies with barley rice and sesame oil. The pancake and chicken perilla seed porridge  stood out as highlights. The set menu offers a substantial amount of food. Overall, it was a positive experience, and I would recommend this place.

This is heaven for vegetarians/pescatarians. We got the set menu - 25 different dishes that all told and everything tasted so good. Not heavily spiced or salted, very clean eating. The roe, snail, and crab cakes were delicious!!! Incredibly sweet crew and explained what everything is. Fun atmosphere, have their own huge parking lot for the plaza which is so rare in ktown! A great birthday meal.

Of all the countless times I've visited Ktown this was my first time at Borit Gogae and was an absolutely wonderful experience. The restaurant offers an extensive banchan spread with barley rice, perfect for crafting your own bibimbap. Lots of plant based side dishes.

The set menu includes an appetizer of pumpkin porridge and nurungji, accompanied by tea and a delightful dessert. While the dukk galbi we tried was just okay, the overall set menu was impressive and something I would definitely return for. Note: you're required to order a minimum of two orders of the set menu.

Every dish tasted homemade and authentically Korean, a detail that I know my parents would particularly appreciate. We visited on a Monday afternoon for a late lunch and found plenty of free parking behind the restaurant.

Overall, Borit Gogae provides a cozy and authentic dining experience that I highly recommend.

Overall the meal was good but nothing special. As a korean it was kinda similar to the random assortment of stuff chucked into a bibimbap at a church lunch iykyk LOL
Th best part was probably the perilla chicken porridge. The marinted pork ribs are a NO for me they are not marinated long enough so only the exterior is coated in sauce and th inside is dry and flavorless.
Also the table got way full and 복잡해. Probably will not come again but glad i tried it at least once. Like. Its not bad. Its just nothing special. I appreciated the dessert though. Didnt appreciate the tone of the waitress with a lot of makeup, really pedantically switching to english to then explain the dishes very slowly even though im fluent in korean, and was in fact there with my parents and sister lol.

First time here and I loved it! The staff was so kind and patient and explained their course menu. They took the time to nicely explain each of the dishes and how to eat them. Delicious and healthy, country-style Korean food. You can ask for more barley rice (we didn't but we observed several tables doing so).  Free parking in the parking lot on the back side of the restaurant.

name: HanEuem by Chef Kang
address: 539 S Western Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90020, USA
reviews: Next to Korea, Los Angeles has the largest population of Korean so we are lucky to have the best chef ! If you are tired of Korean bbq but wants to eat other cuisine thane I would suggest you come here ! We came here 3 years ago when it was first opened from a suggestion from my son and fell in love with this place since!! We love the Korean seafood pancake.. the crust is perfectly brown on the outside while inside is filled with leak, green onion and seafood.. absolutely delicious! The snail salad is outstanding! Yes! Snail.. don’t judge me until you try! The short rib soup is loaded with vegetable!!! Yummy!!

(also posted on their Yelp page)
I had such a great experience here!! I was next door at TPO Coffee and wandered over here for lunch. The food was great, and the service was excellent. Parking was $3 in their lot.

Of course we had to get the soy marinated raw crab, which was my first time eating it. The lady explained that they were out of the Korea-caught crab, but the America-caught ones were better anyway. For $40, it came with five crabs. The lady gave us gloves and explained how to eat the crab mixed with the rice and toppings. It was absolutely delicious. It was even better with soju!

The galbijim with cheese $61 was good, and we also got a pork belly kimchi pancake $22. This was too much food for three people, so we packed leftovers home. I would have liked to try the baby octopus stir fried too. The star of the show was the crab though.

One of the best Korean places I’ve been to. I loved their Pork Belly and Baby octopus dish. It had tons of bean sprouts which seemed a bit odd at first, but completed the dish. Everything was perfectly seasoned. A little sweet and salty but not too much of each. Very big portions and great side dishes.

Love love the food here. It’s soooo good I went there twice in a week — once as soon as I got into LA and then 3 days later with a friend. Had the grilled mackerel, grilled squid and spicy chicken with potato stew and they were all super good. Portions are amazing. Service is friendly although you might have to get the attention from staff for things like more water if you run out. Love the hot barley tea they serve complimentary. Would be awesome to perhaps have a pot on the table for self refills. I’ll be back to try other things on the menu! 😋

Nested in the heart of K-Town, this Korean restaurant serves traditional dishes with a slight modern rendition without straying too far from its root.

The banchan (side dishes) was absolutely delicious; their fish cake is one of the best I've ever had. We ordered two of their most popular items: Braised Wagyu Beef Back Ribs and Pork Belly Kimchi Pancake. The flavor was really good, but it didn't hit the wow factor for me. Warning: everything is really salty, even for someone like me that has a heavier taste. Prepare to chug water and wash down the sodium!

Portions are bigger portions and meant to be shared. Perfect for a large group gathering. The interior looks newly renovated and provides a clean ambiance. It does get quite loud with music blaring (typical though haha). The service was friendly and better than other K-Town spots. However, they seemed to be understaffed and can take awhile to get to you. Reasonably priced, $45-60 per person without drinks.

name: Ddong Ggo
address: 528 S Western Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90020, USA
reviews: Food was phenomenal and service was awesome. They have a galore of drinks and traditional and modern take on Korean food. They make the food right on the spot so it may take a few minutes but it's definitely fresh. So flavorful even if you don't drink I highly recommend this spot for the dishes and finger foods. Cheers to those who do drink. The guy who served us was really nice and attentive to our requests.

Young vibes for late night drinking. Great for large groups or a birthday party maybe. We ordered the rice cakes, small intestines, chicken wings. I don’t think this place is known for food, nor do I recommend the food - I think it’s just to give yourself some sustenance as you keep drinking because even though the place isn’t that ‘nice’, it’s outdoor seating and vibes in crowd is what makes his place a good spot to party. But keep in mind it’s young 20’s.

🥵•𝐇𝐎𝐓•𝐈𝐍•𝐇𝐄𝐑𝐄•🐔🔥 ⁣
•⁣
🥵 It’s getting hot in here! Are you a big fan of hot and spicy 🌶 food? We are! And if you are too, we’d love to recommend 𝘋𝘥𝘰𝘯𝘨 𝘎𝘨𝘰 𝘪𝘯 𝘒𝘵𝘰𝘸𝘯 𝘓𝘈. This place is awesome with their cheezy spicy chicken dish. Who knew chicken and cheese would be a perfect pairing. Start your meal with their unique egg rolls. Totally unexpected and so delish 🤤. Move on to the 🧀 cheezy spicy 🌶 chicken! And end your meal with nothing more perfect than a watermelon tower 🍉. Totally appropriate to cool off the dying taste buds (just kidding)⁣
•⁣⁣
What we recommend:
🔥 Cheezy Spicy Chicken⁣
🥚 Egg Roll⁣
🍉 Watermelon Tower⁣

I had a great time here! I've never been to Korea but was told the vibe is quite similar. We sat outside under the tents and they had heat lamps. Food comes in big portions so be aware when u order; though, u can take them home if u don't finish them. Smoking is allowed in the patio. Service was good, no complaints. Super busy on weekends. Street parking.

Everything was pretty good though a bit pricey overall. My personal favorite was the spicy chicken cheese which had just the right amount of spice. The seafood kimchi pancake was good, surprisingly spicy though it wasn't mentioned in the menu. The beef bulgogi was also good, but pretty much on par with most other places.

Definitely a place to go hang out with friends, less so by yourself.

name: Sun Nong Dan
address: 710 S Western Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90005, USA
reviews:
We ordered one medium Koh Galbi Jim.  Glad we didn't order more, it was way more than enough for 3 Filipina ladies 🤣 though we ate a lot!
It's great value for your money.   I love that it's flavored well and yet not salty at all.  Side dishes were balanced, not too spicy but enough heat.  I enjoyed it very much.
It's unfortunate that we don't have great Korean Restaurant in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida.
This place has $4 valet parking, very reasonable.

I have been holding off on eating at Sun Nong Dan due to the usual long lines and pretty steep prices. But finally decided to try it on a Monday for early dinner. No lines at 6:00pm so that was a huge plus. We ordered the medium kalbi-jim for $89….after eating and seeing how much meat they put into their dishes I think the $89 is a great value. We had enough left overs for 2 more meals! The taste was really good and we added cheese so they did the whole flame show. Can’t wait to go back and try their stews!

A must go place.
